DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRY, TECHNOLOGY AND COMMERCE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 March, on motion by Mr Crean:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr McGauran had moved by way of amendment:
That all words after ``That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
``whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House-

(1) is of the opinion that the very existence of the Discretionary Grants Scheme and the Generic Technologies Scheme, administered by the Industry Research and Development Board, attests to the Government's failure to carry out necessary economic reforms which has resulted in:
(a) the incapacity of Australia's economy to derive the full benefits of technological innovation;
(b) the high cost of capital and general economic conditions which have compromised industry investment, especially in technology-related business strategies; and
(c) the inability of small start-up companies to gain access to suitable private capital backing or industry support at the early stages of product development; and
(2) notes that the extension of these schemes until 1994, which the Bill proposes, is further evidence of the Government's failure in this regard''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The main purpose of the Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Bill is to extend the so-called GIRD scheme, the grants for industry research and development scheme, until 30 June 1994, and a number of related matters. The scheme comprises two elements, namely, discretionary grants and generic technology grants. It was introduced in 1986, although a similar predecessor scheme operated for over a decade before that.

SPEECH.PARA: The grants scheme is complementary to the 150 per cent tax incentive for research and development expenditure implemented after the 1984 election. That-the 150 per cent incentive-was an initiative of the Opposition science and technology policy at that time; but we were happy enough to see the Government take it over. The point is that in the case of some companies developing an innovation, particularly small and often start-up companies, there is not yet a profit stream to enable them to take advantage of the 150 per cent tax incentive; hence the significance of a grant under this GIRD scheme.

The Opposition, somewhat reluctantly, supports this legislation to extend the life of these schemes-the discretionary grants scheme and the generic technology scheme. There is no doubt, of course, that industry research and development is critical to the development of a more internationally competitive industry sector in Australia. That is especially so of the `development' component in research and development, which means the translation of scientific research and innovative ideas into actual industry technology, leading to profitable job generating businesses-sometimes creating entirely new industries, but, more often and more importantly, having the effect of furthering structural change and by creating, revitalising and renewing existing industry.

There has been and remains a great lag in Australia in that area. In science, it can be said that Australia ranks very highly in the world scale. With 0.3 per cent of the world population, we produce about 2 per cent of the world's science, quantified in terms of internationally recognised scientific papers. But in this domain of private industry research and development-as I have said, the translation of scientific research and innovative ideas into actual technologies and job generating industry-Australia has long tended to lag.

Our reluctance in supporting this measure stems not from any lack of appreciation of the importance of industry research and development for the healthy competitive growth of industry in Australia, but from a questioning of the efficacy of the grant process as incentive to increased industrial research and development. The grant process involves an administrative allocation of the available resources-$32m-an onerous task which is undertaken with undoubted competence and integrity by the Industry Research and Development Board. The Opposition's belief is that this sort of resource allocation cannot be effectively carried out by administrative mechanisms. When the chips are down, this is not a process we would like to see governments involved in at all.

While not opposing the extension of the schemes, which the Government itself has given notice will be subject to comprehensive review before committing funds beyond 1994, we would judge that at best the impact on Australia's industry research and development effort and industry growth is marginal. The truth is that what is important for an effective industrial research and development level, new investment and industry development are the financial capacity to research and invest-which is largely a matter of profitability, competition, and an internationally competitive business environment.

That is just what we have not had over most of the life of this Hawke Government, and that is the thrust of the amendment moved by the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), which is to the effect that whilst not refusing to give the Bill a second reading, this House is of the opinion that this measure attests to the Government's failure to carry out important necessary economic reforms.

This amendment involves the whole gamut of policy for economic growth and development-policy to realise the boundless potential of this richly endowed country. Lest one be subjected to charges, as was the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) yesterday by a desperate Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), of selling this country short, let me assure the House that I have great faith in the boundless potential and great future of our Australia.

Currently, however, the Australian economy is in dire straits and we need to recognise that. We have the deepest recession since the Great Depression of the 1930s. Notwithstanding the measure of improvement in the last balance of payments figures, the current account deficit remains stalled, despite the recession, at about 4.5 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP). At that level, the foreign debt problem will continue to intensify. Currently, the gross debt is about $165 billion, which represents more than a fivefold increase under this Government. It will continue to intensify, undermining living standards, constraining future development and making this country extremely vulnerable to external shocks. Let me stress that the country will continue to borrow heavily, going extra into debt at the rate of about $50m a day to pay the interest bill on existing debt!

I referred a moment ago to the correlation between research and development and investment spending on the one hand and profits on the other. I have before me several graphs, one of which appeared in the 12 April issue of the Business Review Weekly. It shows the close correlation between the level of recent profitability in relation to a required return, and investment. When that falls, so does investment-as is happening very strongly at this moment. I seek leave to incorporate that graph in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: It is accepted, as was stated in the debate yesterday, that inflation is coming down. That is important, a very key positive in the present situation. Persistent high inflation is a great distorting influence in the pattern of research and development and investment spending, but the problem is that nothing is being put in place to keep it down. A sound macro-so-called-policy, a consistent sound monetary and fiscal policy, was lacking over the 1987-90 period. As I set out in speaking to the Supply Bills the other night, the Government deliberately eased monetary policy in the early part of 1987 and thereafter, on top of a commodity price surge, and the effect was to dramatically overheat the economy. I elaborated on that the other night.

It is not just a matter of change in the macro area but also of change in the so-called micro area: real industrial relations change in the direction of genuine enterprise bargaining-not what goes by that name in current discussions-and major and urgent change in transport, the waterfront, telecommunications and so on to bring them up, hopefully, to international best practice. These changes are absolutely vital for a low inflation, dynamic, high productivity, high standard of living economy.

Yesterday in debate the Prime Minister pointed proudly to Government activity in the area of tariff reduction as a component of micro-economic reform. Of course, the trouble is that in the 12 March statement announcing the policy of further tariff reduction there was little other than rhetoric and posturing in respect of the areas that really matter-labour market reform and meaningful, effective structural change. The fact is that the two must go hand in hand. The Opposition has repeatedly stated, in supporting and advocating a program of tariff reduction to negligible levels by the year 2000, that that must go hand in hand with fundamental change in the industrial relations area and in the micro-economic area.

As we are under a limitation of time in the debate, I conclude on that note. While the Opposition reluctantly supports this measure, we believe it is essential that proper policies be put in place to generate a dynamic, high productivity, high standard of living economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grace Mr E.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been mentioned by previous speakers, the Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Bill deals with a number of matters within the industry, technology and commerce portfolio. Primarily, the Bill could be described as being of a housekeeping nature, containing as it does a number of corrections to drafting errors in various Acts and certain minor administrative amendments to others.

SPEECH.PARA: However, to say that the Bill is primarily of a housekeeping nature greatly demeans one very important amendment that has been included which will have a significant role to play in the continuing progress of economic reconstruction in the growth of this country. I refer to the Industry Research and Development Act 1986, which operates as an important arm of the Federal Government's program to encourage Australian industry to look to technology, new products and new ways of doing things to maintain growth and increase our export potential.

I think all honourable members will agree that research and development efforts, and the attitude that Australian executives and their shareholders exhibit to research and development, will play their part in determining Australia's place in the world in the years to come. As honourable members are well and truly aware, international trade has grown tremendously over recent years on the back of factors such as the accelerating progress of world industrialisation, the continuing transport revolution and the internationalisation of finance markets. New technology and product innovation have became the order of the day in this increasingly competitive world marketplace.

Paramount among the new technologies that have changed the face of world trade is, of course, the computer revolution. Just as the space race brought with it a range of new and industry-adaptable technology such as teflon products, superglues and heat-resistant tiles, the emergence of computers as an everyday tool in business has thrust secondary industry into a headlong technology race. Competition for new and improved products has been immense. Countries and industries which have failed to meet the challenge of research and development have found it increasingly difficult to meet these new challenges.

Regrettably, it is true to say that Australia missed the boat in the early great leaps forward which occurred in the secondary industry area in the 1960s and 1970s. Although our relatively small population was used as a scapegoat, the truth remains that our lack of government leadership on the issue and our national aversion to meaningful expenditure on research and development precipitated the almost total destruction of our whitegoods, electronics and textile industries against others. The fact is that while we were satisfied to make our living on the back of primary industry and resource exports, and with tried and true technology, we let slip away the lucrative value added market which has been so comprehensively captured by countries such as Japan who have been prepared to forgo short term profits for the sake of a more profitable future.

The saddest aspect of Australia's failure to respond to the manufacturing industry challenges of the 1960s and 1970s is that our political leaders and our industrialists failed to heed the very clear messages of history. By the end of the 1960s it had become patently clear that the two economies which were sustaining the greatest levels of growth were the defeated Axis powers of World War II-Japan and West Germany. To even the most undiscerning commentators the reasons for this phenomenon where abundantly clear. At the end of the war the economies of those two countries had been completely destroyed-bombed out of existence, so to speak. This meant that secondary industry re-establishment had to take place from the ground up.

While Australia, Britain and other members of the Allies went back to post-war industries with the same tools and techniques as before, the Japanese and Germans were rebuilding their industrial enterprises from the ground up; they were completely new. They were not faced with the choice between continuing with the old ways and the expense of tooling up with the new war-induced technology. The new way was the only way they could go. Therefore their manufacturing industries entered the 1950s with a huge advantage in technology over their rivals-an advantage they have been keen to maintain over the years. Although we did not know it at the time, our slowness in responding to the immediate post-war technology boom set the scene for our dramatic failure to compete when the new technology revolution took off in the 1960s and 1970s and for our continuing problems into the 1980s and 1990s.

In the light of our failures in the past, and with new technology now playing a central role in the process of economic growth, it is little wonder that over the last decade almost every commentator and economist in Australia has screamed `high technology' to anybody who would listen. Unlike our forebears in the 1950s and 1960s, they can see the problems that are there for advanced countries coming from behind the eight-ball into the manufacturing industry race. Although it is simplistic to believe that high technology goods such as our touted computer software can carry Australia alone, the fact is that after years of falling behind we have had to find a niche suitable to our talents and to our circumstances.

Australia had to have a government which recognised our problems and had the ability to create a business environment conducive to secondary industry growth. This has been one of the great strengths of this Government. In a direct fashion, the Hawke Government grants for industry research and development scheme, which was part of the Industry Research and Development Act 1986, has played a key role in encouraging Australian companies to invest in new products and product improvement. It has shown industry that the Government is prepared to provide solid backing in the area if the idea is right and the company's research is right.

Two important elements of the grants for industry research and development scheme have been discretionary grants and generic technology grants. Discretionary grants are awarded to companies unable to use the 150 per cent tax incentive, such as new companies developing an innovation which may not turn out a profit for several years. They are the Government's way of assisting innovation in such circumstances. Generic technology grants are awarded to researchers who are involved in research with commercial partners on schemes which have a potential for widespread use. The grants are an important tool in encouraging the best possible outcomes for research.

In the Bill currently before the House, those two grant forms will be extended until 1994. The amendments sanctioning the extensions have been necessary as a result of a sunset provision in the 1986 Act, which stipulated that they should cease as at 30 June 1991. With the passing of this Bill, all the Government's industry research and development support measures will have been extended, and will therefore be complementary.

In its research and development policies, the Hawke Government has worked hard to encourage Australian industry away from its traditional aversion to spending for the medium to long term. Despite the fast-buck merchants who proliferated in the 1980s, Labor has been successful because it has provided a total framework for industrial growth.

Although constrained by the individual policies of the States, the Hawke Government has by and large got the message across that the campaign for a national reconstruction and rejuvenation is in earnest. Our success in various high technology fields, such as the transplant field and the computer software industry, shows that we have the ability, and that is shown also by the results achieved by some of our more adventurous research bodies such as the Garvan Institute and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. Likewise, our universities are producing first-class research results, particularly in the medical area.

The Hawke Government has put in place policies such as the Industry Research and Development Act 1986 which gives R& the public backing it needs to succeed. The Bill before the House, therefore, will ensure that industry has those appropriate policies in place, so that it is able to make medium term research and development decisions with surety. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been said, the Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Bill before us contains, for the most part, provisions of a housekeeping nature, which, as would be known, are supported by the Opposition. However, the provisions dealing with the Industry Research and Development Act 1986 and the enactment of the national procurement and development program agreements do make a number of important changes and offer an opportunity to consider an aspect of the industry research and development scheme which is causing increasing misgivings in the business community.

SPEECH.PARA: In saying that, I refer to the Industry Research and Development Board's conflict of interest guidelines and the manner in which they are being administered. Over the past six months I have received representations from three companies, all of which expressed concern at the operation and conduct of the industry, research and development scheme. In considering their specific complaints, I believe that there are good and necessary grounds for a thorough revision of the scheme's conflict of interest guidelines and the manner of their administration.

On 5 December last year, and prompted by the representations I have referred to, I asked a question on notice which sought to identify the extent to which research grants have been made to applicants who had some association with a member of the Board or with its several committees, schemes or programs. The answer to my question revealed the surprising fact that since 1986-87 almost 18 per cent of approved grants and about 30 per cent of the dollar value of total grants have gone to companies and organisations which had an association with Board and committee members.

Let me immediately say that I have no evidence suggesting any impropriety on the part of individual Board or committee members, or indeed of the Board as a whole. I would like to make that plain. But the Board and the Government must be aware of the dangers which such circumstances hold for an agency which is empowered to administer one of the most significant areas of research funding to Australian industries.

Those dangers are very real and must not be underestimated, for it is surely of some significance that three totally unrelated companies making representations to me about the operation of the industry research and development scheme all mentioned their misgivings about an agency that can allocate 30 per cent of its funding to applicants associated with its membership, while it gathers a reputation as a body which is rejecting countless applications of merit.

One company making these representations had excellent grounds for complaint, as it met all the criteria. It has established a small but impressive export market with a high technology product, yet successive applications over six years for a modest research grant have all failed.

I was disturbed about this and got in touch with the secretariat of the Industry Research and Development Board and it provided me with a copy of the conflict of interest guidelines which govern industry research and development procedures and also a detailed explanation of the way in which these were applied. For example, guideline No. 2 states that:
Where a member is aware of a conflict of interest, the member should advise the meeting and this should be included in the minutes. The member should then leave the room.

The secretariat expressed confidence that these aspects of the conflict of interest guidelines were being closely adhered to, but obviously reservations must be felt about phrases such as `where a member is aware' and `should advise the meeting'. Similar reservations must be felt about the wording of guideline No. 6. I turn to guideline No. 3, which states:
The Board or Committee should decide, in the absence of the member, whether it wants the member to be present and/or participate in discussion or not.
Guideline No. 4 states:
In general, requests from applicants that certain members not see applications be rejected.
I repeat: `requests from applicants that certain members not see applications be rejected'. It continues:
In exceptional cases, where such requests may seem reasonable, the Secretariat as appropriate to discuss the request with the applicant and the relevant Chairman and/or Board Chairman.
Finally, guideline No. 5 provides:

Members who declare an interest will not receive reports or information on those matters in which they have an interest, where their interest is known before meetings. Discussions regarding their interest will be deleted from their copies of the minutes, unless the Board decides that they should be present-

during relevant discussions and decision making. If I can go back to guideline No. 2, it will be recalled that it provides for a member to declare a conflict of interest, for that to be minuted and for the member to leave the room. There is little satisfaction for an applicant in such a procedure, as the documentation containing important commercial information will have already been sighted by a competitor in reaching the decision to disclose a possible conflict of interest in terms of guideline No. 2.

In any event, there is little comfort in all these provisions when guideline No. 4 provides that, `in general, requests from applicants that certain members not see applications be rejected'. It is the wording of guidelines Nos 3, 4 and 5, and their relationship to guidelines Nos 2 and 6, that bothers me very greatly. That also bothers the three companies which have made representations to me on these matters. Also, we know that it has bothered Monash University and ICI. They were joint applicants for a grant and, as disclosed in the Minister's reply to my question on notice, they requested that Board member Mr Hanley, who was associated with the company Memtec Ltd, not be involved in the assessment of their project. Mr Hanley left the room while the matter was discussed, but the Board decided that Mr Hanley should participate and noted that, under the Board's conflict of interest guidelines, requests by grant applicants for certain Board members not to see an application should normally be rejected.

Thus we have a situation where the Government's premier industry research funding agency has not only approved more than $55m over 4 1/2 years to applicants that have an association with Board and committee members but also handles applicants' confidential commercial information in what can only be described as a cavalier fashion.

This raises a number of questions. In how many instances of the 80 grants identified in the answer to my question as having a conflict of interest association with Board or committee members were those members allowed to retain their participation in the decision making process? Is not a considerable commercial insensitivity, at the very least, shown by the Board in having a guideline stating that an applicant's request for his or her application not to be sighted by certain members will generally be rejected?

Is there not a most unsatisfactory contradiction between guidelines Nos 4 and 5 where the former states that requests for applications not to be seen by certain members will generally be rejected, yet the latter states that reports and/or information, presumably in relation to ongoing deliberations, will not be made available to a member where conflict of interest is known beforehand? In other words, a member may be given the application and its documentation but then be excluded from subsequent information about its progress through the Board. There is little comfort to the applicant in such an arrangement.

Is there not also a serious inconsistency between guidelines Nos 4 and 3? The former states that requests that applications not be seen by certain members will generally be rejected and the latter that where the Board or committee may decide that there is a conflict of interest and that a member should be excluded from further participating in that subject.

It is these several aspects of the guidelines which I and many people in the business community find totally unsatisfactory. The circumstances of one of the companies which made representation to me is particularly relevant to the above consideration. This person's product was directly competitive with a product being developed by a member of the Board.

Whilst the rejection of his application was obviously a disappointment, his and my concern is that the Board's conflict of interest guidelines are being administered in a way which means that highly confidential commercial information became available to a competitor company. Further, even if his competitor had admitted to a conflict of interest, it seems very likely that the Board member would have been readmitted to the meeting to participate in the decision making. Even if he had asked for his application not to be disclosed to his competitor, all the available evidence suggests that this was unlikely to be agreed to by the Board.

Perhaps if the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Crean), who is at the table, were to experience the reality of commercial life, he might appreciate why the business community has very good grounds for its growing mistrust of the Board's conduct. In saying that, I want to re-emphasise that I do not have any evidence to question the integrity of individual Board members. However, I am saying that it is totally unsatisfactory for an industry research funding agency to conduct its conflict of interest guidelines in such a manner as to place its members in a position which creates needless and potentially damaging doubts about the agency's impartiality.

For the sake of the excellent work being done by the Industry Research and Development Board in fostering important projects amongst small and medium sized companies with thin capital support, it is not good enough that the business community's trust be jeopardised by, at the very least, imprudent conflict of interest guidelines and their insensitive administration. The work of the industry research and development scheme is so important that its conduct must have all applicants' unequivocal confidence that sensitive commercial information is not being sighted by competitors and that the selection process is, and is seen to be, of unimpeachable integrity.

To achieve this, I suggest that the conflict of interest guidelines need to be redrafted and administered such that, in the first instance, all Board or committee members would be provided with only an applicant's name and a synopsis of the product or process involved in their application. Members would be required to declare a conflict of interest on the basis of that preliminary information. A declaration of conflict of interest will exclude that member from receiving a copy of the applicant's application and supporting documentation; participating in any meeting or discussion at which that application is being considered; and from receiving any reports or other information on Board or committee discussions or decisions. As well, irrespective of whether a conflict of interest has been declared, an applicant must have the right to ask that certain members not be provided with a copy of his application or its supporting documentation and that the request be granted.

The industry research and development scheme provides a valuable role in supporting industrial research and development among companies which would otherwise find it almost impossible to obtain the necessary financial backing. As we all know, Australia is presently at a place in its history where it is a matter of great national importance that industrial research and development be encouraged and its effectiveness maximised. My comments are directed towards both goals, and I would hope that the Minister at the table will treat very seriously the concern and misgivings which are widespread within the relevant community about the operation of the Board and take closely to heart those suggestions which I think would tighten up the conflict of interest requirements very considerably and very properly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elliott Mr R.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Bill continues the Government's real commitment to ensuring that research and development and the broad range of research and development initiatives in industry are given a positive Government impetus and that the programs set in place and the extension of those research programs are treated with priority.

SPEECH.PARA: If one looks at the measures in this Bill and at the measures announced in the industry statement on 12 March and if one takes account of the recent growth in a number of reform areas such as in our telecommunications reform, one will see a common thread running through those arrangements-a commitment to industry, research and development and a recognition on the part of the Government that government has a part to play in many fields, particularly in innovative technology areas, in ensuring that there is a strong scope to provide the stimulus to ensure that research work is undertaken.

I guess it has been one of the features of industrial development in this country that less emphasis has been put on research, in a pure and applied sense, than in many other countries. As other speakers in this debate have said, the fact that in the past we have been able to rely so strongly on primary production and resource development has meant that a lot of inventiveness that was certainly always a feature of our life has not been able to develop to its full potential. The value added aspects of our industrial development have not always been achieved because of a number of factors, particularly the fact that there has been a lack of research effort and a lack of capital for development of product. We have tended to rely on primary products producing the export wealth that we can use to buy imported goods rather than encourage production at home.

The reforms that the Government has progressively undertaken in the area of tariffs have all been part of ensuring that we were internationally competitive and that we were engaged in productive processes that would enable us to compete in the world market. As a result, the recent trade figures show that our export earning potential is growing. It certainly has the potential to grow even further, providing that we recognise both the importance of the research and the development of the value added industries here and the strength of where our real markets are for so many of the products that we develop.

Of course, the real scope for us to become a major exporter and to develop our industry is in the Asian market. Historically, industrial research and development has tended to overlook that potential. Indeed, stories have been told about our trying in the past to engage in export of refined wool products at the same time as direct participants in the industry were saying, `Well, don't worry about that, we can just sell the raw material overseas and we do not have to worry about the productive processes down the line'.

The legislation currently before us provides the scope for companies which are seeking to develop that research effort, both in an individual sense and in a collective and collaborative way between research institutions-be they the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) or other research establishments-and industry to apply that research endeavour in a more rigorous way. I think this is particularly important. Only in recent weeks we saw the example of an Australian company in the field of aviation winning a major contract for the development and manufacture of parts of the tail of the new Boeing aircraft. That is the sort of thing that can be achieved.

However, it will be achieved only if we set in place arrangements that provide a positive stimulus and a sense of purpose to the research effort that we undertake. Many members opposite constantly refer to this in a negative way, saying that is picking winners. The fact that we set up a process that gives very positive tax benefit to people to engage in research is fundamental. This scheme provides that companies that are not covered by the normal tax concession processes for research will be covered by the discretionary grants arrangements. In addition, there are the generic technology grants arrangements, which through this Bill are being extended to June 1994.

All of those things are important, because many small businesses that actually develop in the technological and electrical fields need only fairly modest assistance to develop their products to a stage where, with financial support and stimulus and the capital that is provided, they can go on to become substantial exporters.

Recently, I had the opportunity to visit the Alcatel operation at Botany in Sydney. There is no doubt that its achievements, considering the potential of what that company could actually achieve in Asia in the telecommunications area, are a great reflection on the skill and capacity of the researchers in Australia and also on their capacity to link that into international operations, as I say, particularly in the Asian market.

We can achieve more of those sorts of things if we are conscious of the fact that we must have an ethos about the development of such industries. We do not have to say that they all need to have protective tariffs and that sort of thing. That was the way of the past and clearly that is now inappropriate. What we do need to say is that, in something like our telecommunications reform measures, to which we have devoted a lot of energy, we are very conscious of the industry potential that those reforms should offer.

Part of the process of establishing the reforms in telecommunications surely should be that the skills and the opportunities that reform process offers actually provide wealth and advancement for the Australian industry as a whole. That can be achieved. The way to do that, in part, is for the Government to provide research assistance that can be targeted to those important areas.

In this respect, there is a great deal of opportunity in the various medical technology fields. Organisations such as the CSIRO play a particularly important role in conducting research in the area of its own endeavour and assisting with research skills in the medical faculties of universities, as well as with companies in the pharmaceuticals area, for example, where again there is a tremendous opportunity for a collective effort to achieve development in the pharmaceuticals area. This can be done if we provide the sort of stimulus provided through these sorts of grants.

Only recently I made a visit to Westmead Hospital in my electorate, where medical researchers are engaging in particularly practical research projects in the field of development of treatment for the elderly. Their projects include more appropriate ways of developing the technology for hip replacements, for example, so that, as the population ages, we can benefit from innovations in medical technology. The many elderly people who need hip replacement operations will no longer require the difficult and long rehabilitation processes that go with them.

The medical technology research that is going on at Westmead Hospital has the potential to be a great asset to medical science not only in this country but also in the world. One of the difficulties that institutions like Westmead Hospital and its research institute have concerns provision of the funding to get many of these projects going in the first place. We need to ensure that, until something tangible comes out in the way of results, such projects will be adequately funded in the initial stages.

It is important for government to play a part in that process. Often once people have seen that something is starting to flow from it they will come along and be prepared to take up research effort. However, to have the researchers and academics able to do the research devote the time to it, means that the resources must be there in the first place. They need the resources to enable them to undertake the very painstaking work needed to establish that their field of inquiry has a purpose and is going to achieve a result. This needs government support in the field of industry research grants and it requires working in a collaborative way, because so many of these projects are indeed an amalgam of effort between companies, between the CSIRO or other research organisations.

The best way of achieving that is actually to have some positive and collaborative way of achieving that development. So many people in the research field say to me that what they really need is just a seeding sort of grant to get those endeavours going. Once they get that, they can then move on and achieve results which would mean no doubt that many people, if they were successful, would be able to move very constructively forward, once they saw the value and the real earning capacity that those inventive processes offer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose the amendment and to respond to a number of points that have been made in the debate. The amendment itself is a confusing one. On the face of it, it seeks to be critical of the Government's failure to carry out necessary economic reforms, which has resulted in a number of things: the incapacity of Australia's economy to derive full benefits from technological innovation, the high cost of capital and the inability of small start-up companies to access capital. But in the context of that criticism, it opposes the extension of a measure that has been an integral part of the Government's fundamental economic reforms to achieve the result of linking the application to the discovery.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, I find it a confusing amendment. I can understand the confusion, given the fact that the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), who moved it, seems to think that the solution to these problems is a free market one, where all one really has to do is get the economic fundamentals operating correctly for the necessary investment to take place and industry to make the decisions necessary to enable the better application of our discovery.

Let me just go to those points because the statistics reveal that when this Government came to power the percentage of the gross domestic product that the private sector was prepared to spend on research and development was 0.2 per cent. That was, in essence, leaving it to the market. It was leaving it to the market in circumstances in which, for a number of years, the cost of capital was not the problem. It was leaving it to the market in circumstances in which plenty of investment was available, but it still did not happen.

Under the Labor Party, however, the reality has been that that 0.2 per cent of gross domestic product has risen to 0.52 per cent. The contribution of the private sector has, in fact, seen a trebling of its expenditure on research and development. This has occurred because schemes such as the grants for industrial research and development have been there as an integral part of encouraging and fostering the framework in which the private sector responds better.

Let me just briefly explain what our framework for encouraging that outcome has been. It has been built around three very important planks in science and technology policy: firstly, continuing to foster the environment for the excellence of our research effort, which is world-recognised; secondly, ensuring that there is better cooperation between the competing research endeavours, in both the public and the private sector; and, thirdly, ensuring that we are not just clever at discovering things but that we become more clever at developing and applying, in commercial terms, the outcome of that discovery.

Under the Government's approach to science and technology, to meet the first point the Government has secured the science and research base in this country. The last Budget, for example, saw a 2.3 per cent real increase in expenditure on science and research in this country against, for Budget outlays generally, a cut of 0.6 per cent.

Towards the end of last year, we saw the commitment to guaranteeing triennium funding for the three science agencies. We saw the increase in the salaries of the scientists employed by the CSIRO, and we are pursuing the other issues going to the question of capital infrastructure and the supplementation of the salaries issues to ensure that the research base for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and related agencies is not cut into. We have seen the development of setting external targets for the agencies to obtain funding from the private sector-all of which has been able to be retained by those agencies-which has not only forged better linkages, but which has given a much more solid funding base.

In overall terms, the Government's commitment and public expenditure on R& in this country is high by Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development standards. This country has fallen down in the past-and we are starting to redress it, but we still have a long way to go-because the private sector has not seen the same need to concentrate the effort and expenditure on expanding its R& effort to ensure a more competitive position. A nation cannot become competitive unless it is prepared to be innovative and it cannot be innovative unless it is prepared to spend money in the development of research.

Under this Government we have seen a number of programs-this Bill is but one of them-which have fostered an environment that has seen a trebling in private sector R& expenditure. There is the 150 per cent tax concession that the Government announced in the March economic statement, the extension indefinitely of a tax concession for eligible R&. There is the external funding, which I have alluded to, which has seen much stronger linkages between not only the science agencies but also the universities. Better linkages between industry and our research effort is resulting in better applications, but also involves industry being prepared to support the research effort not just verbally but by putting its money in as well.

The cooperative research centre program-the first 15 centres have been announced-in essence has been a strategy to get linkages between the public and private research effort in this country and to get linkages between industry and research in this country. The Government, whilst it made a commitment to an additional $100m over the next five years to fund that, has used that as leverage to get a multiplier impact. That $100m will at least be matched by participating agencies and a substantial proportion of that will be coming from the private sector.

Those policies to date have seen a trebling in private sector expenditure on R&; they will continue to see growth in private sector R&. In fact, until the recent recession, the reality was that expenditure by the private sector on R& in this country had been the fastest of all the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries-not because we allowed the market to finally bring a realisation to these companies that they should be starting to spend, but because we have gone out and prodded them, levered them and given them assistance. That is why this measure and its extension is an important recognition of that approach, of that strategy. It has worked and it will continue to work. It has worked only because we have had that strategy. The alternative being proposed in this wishy-washy amendment which effectively says, `Let us get out of all these things; leave it to the market and everything will be rosy,' has failed this country in the past and it will fail it in the future. It is for that reason that we oppose the amendment that is proposed. The honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) raised the question of conflict of interest and whilst it is not technically an issue in the Bill before the House, I take the opportunity to respond because I think the issue that he raises is his concern, but I think it is a misplaced concern.

I say that for two reasons. The conflict of interest test has been rigorously applied in terms of the grants for industry research and development (GIRD) scheme. For the reasons that the honourable member raised-it can be open to criticism; certain interests might be looked after at the expense of others-a very rigorous approach has been adopted to circumstances in which a conflict should be declared. I think that point should be understood when looking at the absolute figures in terms of how many conflicts are registered. The figures appear high, but that is because of the rigour of the circumstance and the conditions under which conflicts are registered.

I would like to give an example, because I had these figures drawn out and I think they have probably been forwarded to the honourable member for Warringah in response to the question he had on the Notice Paper. In the two-year period ending 30 December 1990, the Board recorded 75 instances of conflict of interest-75 out of some 246. But of those 75 instances, 32 involved a direct conflict of interest where a member was an employee of an applicant or owned shares in the applicant. Of the 32 instances, eight involved the CSIRO during the period when Dr Colin Adam was a director of the CSIRO's Institute of Industrial Technology. If we take those eight instances away from the 32, we see that 24 out of 246 instances involved a direct conflict of interest. Another five of the 75 instances of conflict of interest involved a less direct conflict of interest where the member or his employer was associated with the applicant's commercial or research collaborator.

In these cases, the member's organisation did not receive funds, although it could have benefited indirectly from a successful application. A total of 37 conflicts occurred where the member, or his employer, was affiliated with the applicant in some way, through its being a parent or subsidy company, through the provision of professional advice or as a competitor. In one case-and I guess this is the one to which the honourable member for Warringah referred when he mentioned the cavalier approach in terms of the response to Monash University's application-the conflict of interest was requested by the applicant, but the member's exclusion from the debate was subsequently disallowed by the Board. In answer to the question about how many were in that category, it would seem on this information that there was only one-one of the 75, but of the 75, 24 only involved a direct conflict of interest.

Another aspect of this question, and the figures do not precisely overlap because they relate to different periods of time, is that there were many applications associated with members which were rejected. For example, there were 65 rejections between 1987 and 1990. That is the first point. I think we have to get into perspective the significance of these conflicts of interest in the total picture.

The second point is that even if people think that 24 out of 75 is still a high number, they have to understand the nature of this Board. What we as a government have set about to do is ensure that we have the highest calibre of people on this Board-people who have the expertise and the experience in knowing where the research is at and where industry should be going. They are the people whom we have asked to give their time in assisting us to get this country going in the right direction.

The honourable member for Warringah has acknowledged the capacity of those people on the Board. He does not impugn any of them, and I accept his comment in that regard-indeed, I welcome it. But I just make the point that if we have been so successful in getting the highest calibre of people on the Board, is it unusual for them to be involved in some of the applications that come before the Board, given that the people on the Board have been successful, effective and know where they are going? I do not find that strange at all.

What I think one has to do is not just criticise the numbers, but assert more effectively that the scheme is not being administered properly. I do not think, on the face of the figures and the statistics, that one can do that. I hope, in going to those points, that I have helped allay some of concerns that the honourable member for Warringah has expressed. The amendments to the parent Act contained in the royalty amendment Bill will enable the efficient determination and collection of royalties from the North West Shelf project, which is now the only region offshore that is subject to these royalties. As a result of this legislation, an interim royalty will be paid by the producers in circumstances where full agreement on an actual level of payment is yet to be finalised. Once agreement has been reached, adjustments to the interim royalty payment will be made. Any overpayment to the producers is required to be paid back within 28 days. Any royalty payment which has been made by the producers will now be considered as an interim payment until such time as the full details of the royalty calculation have been verified and accepted.

The adjustment to royalty in cases of overpayment or underpayment will be facilitated and, indeed, where there has been an overpayment there will be effectively another 28-day period in which the adjustment will be made by a reduction to the subsequent royalty payment required. So on both sides of that equation there is a similar period. Overpayments are required in 28 days and, by one method or another, refunds from the Government to the producers are also required within one calendar month by a downward reduction to the next royalty payment.

I make the point, however, that sometimes there can be quite massive amounts involved, as in the extraordinary circumstances of the excise tariff saga in 1990 and the incorrect ruling by the Government relating to rates of excise payable by the Bass Strait oil producers. Through its action in relinquishing those four permits Chevron has shown not only to Australia but to the rest of the world that it is an environmentally responsible company.

Perth oil explorer Petroz NL, to which the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) referred, still holds the remaining permit, and this Government has asked Petroz to relinquish its title to the acreage. If Petroz had relinquished the permit to the Government of its own accord there would now be no need for this section of the legislation. I therefore appeal to Petroz to attend to its environmental responsibilities and follow Chevron's lead by voluntarily surrendering its exploration permit now.

Our Great Barrier Reef is the largest system of corals and associated life forms in the world. It is encompassed in a marine park within the Great Barrier Reef region covering an area of some 350,000 square kilometres on the Australian continental shelf. The reef is a complex 2,000-kilometre-long maze of about 2,600 individual reefs; the habitat of some 1,500 species of fish, 350 species of hard coral, 4,000 molluscs and 240 species of birds. The reef may be the last place on earth in which dugong-an endangered species-are still common and at this stage not in jeopardy.

In the north the reef is narrow and its eastern edge is marked by a series of narrow ribbon reefs, but in the southern areas it broadens out and presents a vast wilderness of patch reefs. Tropical reef ecosystems are diverse, complex and highly productive. The coral reefs, mangroves and seagrass beds are major components. Because of the low physical energy prevailing generally inside the Great Barrier Reef lagoon, beaches and inter-reefal areas are also biologically diverse and very active.

Water circulation within the Great Barrier Reef lagoon maintains links between reefs. This means that in the instance of an oil spill the events that may occur on one reef could possibly occur on other reefs, even on those reefs that are considerably downstream from the originally affected reef. It seems, from past experience of the petroleum and oil transport industries, that there will always be some risk of a blow-out or spill, even if the technology for prevention and clean-up improves over time. The probability of risk depends on many factors, including the prospectivity of the areas, the technology used for exploration and production, safety measures taken and, of course, weather.

If a spill did occur, wind-generated surface currents are likely to be the dominant factor in the movement of oil, and winds throughout the year are predominantly from the south-east or east. The most likely movement of an oil spill in the Coral Sea is, therefore, onto the Queensland continental shelf, although the direction and the speed will depend on the winds, the tides and the currents that are prevailing at that particular time.

The east Australia current flows to the south along the continental shelf over most of the areas adjacent to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. The large scale ocean currents are likely to be less important than the wind-generated currents in the movement of oil spills. The most likely direction of movement of an oil spill by wind-generated currents from any of those areas would be west-north-west, although there may be considerable variability associated with other influences, such as underlying ocean currents.

Corals are susceptible to impacts from oil, both from acute and chronic events. The extent of the impact will depend on the volume, the frequency and the duration of the spill and of the character of the oil being spilt. Spills off the Caribbean coast of Panama have shown extensive mortality of corals. The sublethal effects of chronic spills can be extensive and serious through changes to community structure. Invertebrate animals associated with coral reefs can also suffer immediate mortality from oil spills. Mangrove ecosystems are particularly susceptible to the effects of oil and the mortality occurs through the smothering of the tree roots. The problems can become compounded by the entrapment of oil within the mangroves and the sediments.

We know also that the effect of oil on seagrass beds and on invertebrate fauna living in or on the beds is variable, ranging from catastrophic to slight. Recolonisation can be rapid, although entrapment of oil can be a problem, and the vertebrate fauna such as our seabirds and whales can be seriously affected by oil.
According to the 1986 summer edition of the international marine journal Oceanus:

. . . the increasing use of Great Barrier Reef waters for navigating large vessels raises concerns over the risks and repercussions of shipping accidents . . . The potential clearly exists for more serious accidents that could possibly lead to major oil spills.

Clearly, there are enough risks facing our magnificent marine park outside this Government's control, such as spills by tankers travelling past the area, without contributing to them by allowing oil exploration in and around the area. I commend the Government for its strong stand in this regard.
Australia's determination to protect its precious reef ecosystem is famous. According again to Oceanus in its summer 1986 edition:

The Great Barrier Reef is unique, and the commitment of the Australian people to its conservation is great. This commitment has led to the establishment of legislation and a management system in which conservation is the dominant theme, with reasonable use of the reef's resources being encouraged. The public participates in decision-making, and is to a degree self-regulating. The (Great Barrier Reef Marine Park) Authority acts as the trustee of the Great Barrier Reef, on behalf of the people of Australia.
Clearly, the system of management of the Great Barrier Reef is seen as a good example of effective conservation of a treasured area and this Bill will help Australia maintain that reputation.

I emphasise again that the Great Barrier Reef is part of Australia's heritage. Its sapphire and emerald waters house layer upon layer of countless species of marine animals and its undersea canyons and walls are lined with living corals. Where these giant coral bones break the surface there are islands, golden sands and green palms. This incredible ecosystem, if considered as a single entity, could be the largest living thing on this planet and undoubtedly our greatest living landscape. It would take only one oil spill or accident in the vicinity of the Great Barrier Reef to destroy whole sections of the reef's ecology and cripple its beauty for an incalculable length of time.

I commend this Bill to the House as I believe that by terminating any remaining oil exploration permits in and around the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park we will be guarding against the destruction of this national treasure for the benefit of the generations that follow us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who began it?

—I acknowledge the initiative of the previous Government, to which the honourable member for Prospect is referring. I want to make a couple of comments on behalf of seas in general. This Bill will enable the Government-
I insert `and the Parliament'-
to terminate the remaining permit in the region.

As has been pointed out very clearly, the Opposition supports the legislation. I believe that the Opposition's support reflects its deep and commonsense approach to conservation matters in general. Finally, the Bill refers to royalties and matters related to royalties with regard to the operations of oil companies and gas extracting companies off the north-west coast and in other areas. I would be interested to know the total cost of operating the natural gas projects on the North West Shelf. Perhaps the Minister will be able to tell us. I know that there is a great deal of expense involved in converting natural gas to liquefied natural gas. I understand that the cooling process required to make natural gas into liquid natural gas is an extremely large operation, the natural gas having to be cooled on site to minus 162 degrees Centigrade. It is then placed in ships and exported overseas-mainly to Japan, at the moment.

Specially constructed ships had to be developed for that operation. In Japan last year I visited the Tokyo gasworks and learnt quite a lot about the ships. The Japanese were able to use the liquefied natural gas in the operation of their motors. The interesting thing was that when the gas in its liquid state, cooled to minus 162 degrees Centigrade, arrived at the gasworks in Tokyo they had massive amounts of cooling power available. At very small expense, the Japanese are able to use the sea water from Tokyo Bay to raise the temperature of the liquefied natural gas to bring it back to the operating temperature for natural gas. There were vast amounts of cooling available and the Japanese have been able to use this cooling power, which is available at virtually no cost, and build giant warehouses where they make substantial returns from the deep freezing of vast quantities of tuna and so on. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a Federal member whose electorate encompasses part of the Great Barrier Reef, it is understandable why I would welcome the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Amendment Bill 1991 and the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Royalty) Amendment Bill 1991. SPEECH.PARA: I also place on record my commendation of the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths). I believe that he has achieved something that will be applauded by industry, environmentalists and the general public. What we have here is a willingness of parties-government, environmentalists and industry-to come together, sit down and think through an issue. Clearly, Chevron has understood this issue to be environmentally important to Australia. So I place on the record my commendation of Chevron for being an environmentally responsible company. This demonstrates what can be achieved if one sits down and talks; that more can be achieved if one uses sugar rather than lemon.

As honourable members may be aware, for the last eight months I have been involved in an inquiry which is looking at the petroleum industry generally. I hope that the consultative, consensus approach that has come through in this legislation will continue to apply as the committee that I am working with sits down not only with petroleum companies but also with other peak bodies to solve a number of the problems that have been besetting service station proprietors, dealers, distributors, motorists and, in fact, in some cases the companies themselves.

The report has been released. I am pleased to say that I have made sure that it is available to the Opposition. I made sure that the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer), the Opposition spokesman for energy, has it. I have also ensured that other interested members of the Parliament have the report. I am most pleased that there has been some National Party support in the person of Bob Katter in Queensland.

In the time available to me, I want to raise the concerns that I have that if there is not a willingness to sit down there will be confrontation, and confrontation never really achieve very much. Regrettably at the moment, despite the very sensible recommendations that have been accepted by the Australian Automobile Association, the Australian Petroleum Agents and Distributors Association, the Motor Traders Association, service groups, small industry groups and others, a couple of companies are running around trying to distort the debate.

That is not the position of BP Australia Ltd. On 26 April, Dr Charles Bowman, the Managing Director of BP Australia, released a statement on the report. His comments were constructive and positive and addressed the issues. He did not agree with everything that we are trying to do but he demonstrated what I am saying-that we need to talk. He said:
In summary, there is sufficient that is positive in the suggestions put forward which warrants a closer review by BP and other market players.

I am using this chamber to try to signal to the other companies that there is a need for this. After all, this is about the issues of micro-economic reform. A change has been initiated by this Government, not just in terms of oil exploration, which is the subject of the legislation before us, but in terms of the preservation and better use of our resources; in terms of trying to ensure that industry is able to access fuel at the cheapest possible price.

Regrettably, in the past there have been major anomalies which have existed because of, I suppose, attitudes and policies. Take, for instance, the temperature variation issue. I am told by the Automobile Association of Australia that it has argued for 20 years that there is a massive loss to industry, dealers, service station proprietors and, ultimately, consumers in terms of the way in which petrol is delivered.

As you would understand, Mr Deputy Speaker, there is actually a loss in volume of fuel as it is heated. The temperature is normally corrected back to the international level of 15 degrees centigrade. But people who buy fuel in country areas, in the tropics and even in Sydney where the temperature can be between 25 and 35 degrees, can suffer a major loss.

Unfortunately, the Australian Institute of Petroleum Ltd, Mobile Oil Australia Ltd and a couple of others are running a line that that is a non-issue, that it is a nonsense. What I am saying here is that we need to agree to sit down and talk these things through. Back in 1980 the Fraser Government rightly, correctly and with great initiative brought down sites and franchise legislation. That Government tried to resolve the problems that existed in the petroleum industry. Unfortunately, the outcome was not as positive as it would have hoped.

In those days there were some 20,000 service stations; today there are between 8,000 and 10,000, depending on the figures that are used. In those days, there were 2,500 distributors; today there are some 500 distributors. In those days the companies had 426 sites and they controlled about four per cent of volume. They still have 426 sites, but today they control about 16 per cent of volume. That does not include the fuel sold on company paper, the equity deals that they have entered into or the diesel stops and so on.

The committee has asked for a proper, tolerant debate. We do not want a brawl, we do not want to go out and go headhunting; instead, we want some even playing rules. I suppose it is like the State of Origin. Most honourable members who come from Queensland or New South Wales understand the concept of the State of Origin. What we have there are basic rules. We have an independent referee and independent touch judges. The teams then go out, and may the best team win. If a person wants to nick down the sideline, hoping he can get around Meninga without being sent 15 metres into the crowd or something, he might risk that; if he wants to plod along with the forwards up the centre, he might risk that. A person knows when he is playing in the State of Origin that if someone head-high tackles him, then he can call on the independent referee and the aggressor could well be sent into the sin bin.

Unfortunately, in the petroleum industry today if the oil company tackles someone head-high, he gets sent off because it is the oil company's referee. We have some real problems within the industry. I am hoping that in the next couple of weeks as I move around Australia, meet with representatives of the Australian Institute of Petroleum Ltd (AIP), and continue to talk with representatives of the service station industry, I can come up with some answers-answers that I believe are necessary.

We need to change the sites legislation-not to have mad regulation, but just to strengthen the existing regulations and laws. We need a model franchise Act; we need a model franchise agreement. We also need to ensure that there is an ombudsman. I raise the point that at the moment the AIP is saying, `We want to regulate, to bring in some sort of referee system'.

I remind honourable members that the banking industry brought about its own ombudsman structure on a voluntary basis. Very shortly we will find that the insurance industry will bring about its own model on a voluntary basis. There is no reason why the oil industry should not be required-and I hope not by legislation, but certainly on a voluntary basis-to establish a fair and independent ombudsman system.

Again, I have heard honourable members on the other side say that we ought to have fair rights for small business people. I notice that the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) has just walked into the chamber. He has taken up the banner for small business people in the past. We need to ensure that section 52a of the Trade Practices Act, on unconscionable conduct, applies to small business people to give them a chance. I suppose we are really saying, `Let us sit down and talk it through, and let us ultimately end up with a system where service station proprietors have a right to buy from any supplier at the lowest possible wholesale price that is available'.

These are the sorts of things the report recommends. We are not out to restructure the law, to legislate or to reregulate. We want an even playing field. As I said with the analogy of the State of Origin; we want to ensure that the people who are contributing to Australia-they employ a lot of people at the distribution and retail levels-have a fair go; we want to ensure that the oil companies get a fair return on the massive billions of dollars they have invested.

I suggest that we will achieve this if we can get rid of the nonsense that the AIP is now running with. It is trying to run the line that it is all going to regulate the industry again. We want to take the good rules and strengthen them and, where the industry can do its own thing, let it do it.

I notice the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall) has come into the chamber. His report was a breakthrough in some of these areas. He first signalled to the marketplace that there was a need for change. What we are really saying in this committee is that we want to take up some of the recommendations that the Minister and other members of his committee put forward-and they came from both sides of the House-and we want to ensure they apply fairly to the oil industry.

The Minister for Resources has been able to achieve these outcomes today by consultation, cooperation and understanding the broad needs as well as the specific needs. I only hope that in the next few weeks we can achieve the same results.

We need to ensure that the nonsense is cast aside. We must leave out the party politics and get down to what is fair and reasonable. I advocate that, if the oil companies, through the AIP or individually, are willing to do this with the motor trades associations of Australia, with the service station associations, with the Australian Automobile Association and other groups, then that shall be the outcome eventually.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few remarks on the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Amendment Bill and the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Royalty) Amendment Bill because of a concern I have about several areas relating to the availability and supply of oil, both onshore and offshore. It was worth observing the nature and practice of the extent to which that freezing ability was used in conjunction with the storage of many highly perishable products, particularly tuna, including tuna from Australia, by the Japanese. We really do not utilise our resources in the way we might, and I thought that the observations of the honourable member for Macquarie were quite correct.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, I agree with the observations and worries of the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), the preceding speaker, about the availability of fuel supplies to petroleum outlets. There is significant difficulty, I know, in parts of Queensland and elsewhere in Australia with the distribution of fuel. I have been given various reasons why there is such a fuel price variation around Australia, but I have always found them to be inexplicable. There is certainly, in rural areas and outback Australia, a price differential which makes the mouths of people from those areas water when they pass by a city bowser, particularly in Brisbane, Sydney or Melbourne, and see that quite frequently the fuel is available for up to 15c, 20c and even more per litre below the price that they pay and pay consistently. There is inevitably a concern about this in much of Australia.

I see the shadow Minister for tourism and aviation, the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), seated at the table. There is no doubt as to the impact of this problem on the whole field of tourism, and the degree to which we prejudice our productive industries and our tourists outside the main cities is a problem. So the observations of the previous speaker about his concern for equal access to fuel for private retailers-that is, petrol retailers-and the extent to which there are price differentials I think are correct, and it is a major problem. I know that governments cannot by regulation easily control these differentials, but there is a real difficulty there and that we cannot overcome it I think is a pity. Although I do not want to see undue government intervention, it concerns me that the impact of the present price differential is to the disadvantage both of productive industry and of tourists around Australia.

I want to say several things about these two pieces of legislation before us. As we are endorsing the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Amendment Bill we cannot be said to oppose it. It is worth observing, firstly, that any improvement in efficiency in the determination of royalties needs to be commended. But the very fact that there is a secondary tax on an industry is something that has always worried me. I know why it is there; I know governments have to raise moneys. I know States have charged royalties, and the Federal Government long ago decided it might as well be in on the act. But secondary taxes have concerned me in that they, like so many other aspects of our society, are a deterrent rather than an encouragement to the generation of economic activity.

I understand why those secondary taxes are there. I know that both sides of the House have supported the maintenance and continuity of royalties. Those taxes and the resource rent tax-which we will talk about on another occasion in the House-exist because it is thought that the oil companies are on a good thing. It has always seemed to me to be perhaps not the way that we in government should go about things. What we ought to be doing is trying to encourage production. We are in a devil of an economic mess. That has really been the subject of debate in this House for a fortnight. We register, as we move around, the economic statistics that are forthcoming. We are aware of the rising burden of debt, the enormous lift in unemployment, and we are concerned that, as Senator Peter Walsh has said, we could be moving into a depression.

These circumstances have to be redressed by looking at how we can encourage productive activity. Sure, in a minimal way, we can adjust the administrative arrangements in order perhaps to get greater equity in the determination of royalties, but really we would be better off if we did not have royalties or secondary tax but applied one tax system and that tax system took off the profits in a fair and equitable way and left encouragement for people to produce.

Sure, royalties are an established fact. If States attract them, why should we not also? I understand that there is a resource there which has a public value and a public significance. The Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Amendment Bill also refers to the Great Barrier Reef. Nobody in his right mind wants a spillage of oil. The Exxon Valdez disaster highlighted the implications, particularly for any place with a unique and fragile environment. I suppose that the fires and the destruction brought on the oilfields and oilwells in Kuwait by Saddam Hussein and his forces constitute one of the great environmental disasters of all time.

As far as oil exploration is concerned, we must recognise that the techniques are changing. Whilst I accept and believe that there should be no exploration on the Great Barrier Reef, I do not think that should apply to seismic exploration. I will make two points about exploration. First, as far as I am concerned, seismic exploration should be capable of being undertaken right through the Australian economic zone.
