That is certainly not going to be the case, although of course BMR, which has a much wider brief than simply petroleum matters, will engage in scientific work relating to non-petroleum exploration areas--
—What about aerial evaluation by BMR?

—I can understand the sensitivity of the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) to the matters that have just been raised, and quite explicitly put, before the House. The right honourable member for New England actively advocated the continuation of seismic surveys in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. What I am stating on the record is that there is a clear difference between what appears to be the attitude of the National Party to seismic surveying in the Great Barrier Reef, and the Government's position, which is totally and absolutely against any such seismic surveying. It is consistent with the Government's attitude to one of the seven great wonders of the world that we really want to send a powerful and unequivocal signal-that is consistent with our response to the termination of Petroz's leases in the area within the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park-that not now, nor in the future, should there be any possibility of oil exploration and production in the Great Barrier Reef.

SPEECH.PARA: I go briefly to some of the other issues raised. The Leader of the National Party, and I think also the right honourable member for New England, went to the issue of the 28 days. In a situation where the producers are assessed as having underpaid royalty, the outstanding amount is required within 28 days from the date of the final assessment being issued by the designated authority. This period corresponds with the timeframe that exists with respect to the payment of normal royalty on a month on month basis and compares favourably with the arrangements that exist for company tax and resource rent tax and also those that apply for crude oil excise payments.

The amounts of royalty likely to fall within this category are expected to be relatively minor in nature as they reflect corrections to previous calculations. So where there was a suggestion that we are talking about very large amounts of money, I think that is unlikely to be the case. In the case of an overpayment of royalty, the Commonwealth would make a refund within a month by crediting the producer's royalty liability in the following month by the amount of the overpayment. I also say that the $200m referred to by the Leader of the National Party was an excise adjustment, not royalty; the amounts of money involved in royalties are, by definition, considerably smaller.

The other matter raised by the right honourable member for New England that I want briefly to go to was the issue of the attractiveness of Australia for investment; that is, that we do not want to take any action that would deter interest in-I am paraphrasing him-exploration and production. I think in these areas we are often our own worst enemy; that is, we are sometimes prepared to argue a view that is totally inconsistent with international opinion-and this is just a classic example.

I am not sure whether the right honourable member for New England is aware of the Robertson survey, which clearly is an internationally well regarded survey of 66 international oil companies that are pre-eminent in the field of oil and gas exploration. The survey, which was released some six or seven weeks ago, ranked Australia at No. 4 internationally as the most desirable place for investment dollars to be directed for oil and gas exploration.

Again we can be subjective, or we can attempt to be objective, but I think we would all agree that, if we are putting these matters before the bar of international oil and gas exploration opinion, and if we accept, as I think we must, that the Robertson survey is one of considerable importance, then we ought to accept its findings. Just concluding on that issue, I might add that we jumped--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about compensation?

—Yes, I will come to that in a moment. On this, we jumped from No. 20 last year to No. 4 this year. So, I think we can say that the objective international opinion is that Australia is a very good host country for oil and gas exploration, and we ought to be talking that up, not talking it down.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to the matter of the environment and oil and gas exploration. I shall keep my comments brief-I do have some notes, but I will not refer to them. In relation to this whole issue, I think it is worth making a couple of points. The first is that in Australia's less than 30 years of offshore oil and gas exploration and production, it has produced some 2,600 million barrels of oil and during that total period we have spilt 350 barrels of oil. If my memory serves me correctly-one should refer to notes-my calculation was that this represents 0.0001 per cent-a minuscule quantity and one which, in terms of offshore oil and gas exploration, gives us the best record bar none.

As well, in this context I might say that mother nature herself is sometimes `guilty' of spilling oil. A phenomenon in offshore Australia is natural leakage. There was one incident that I recall in the Otway Basin where the equivalent of some 7,500 barrels of oil spilt, I think it was in 1988, as a result of natural leakage, that is, as a result of mother nature acting in her sometimes capricious manner. When putting that natural leakage, in one incident alone, against the 350 barrels spilt in the whole of Australia's offshore oil and gas exploration and production industry, that puts the matter into some overall context.

I might also say that, where organisations such as Greenpeace propose a ban on our offshore oil and gas exploration, they ought to think very seriously about the implications of that. There are enormous economic implications, of course, but moreover, and I suspect more importantly for Greenpeace, there are significant environmental implications; that is, were we to ban offshore oil and gas exploration in this country, we would be required by definition to import oil from other countries. By and large, that oil is a heavy bituminous type of oil, unlike our light sweet crudes. It would have to be transited to this country by a tanker. Clearly, the major danger of oil spills on the oceans is related to tanker traffic, and one can refer, for example, to the Exxon Valdez incident and a number of others which, regrettably, are just part of modern-day industrial societies.

If that were the case, we would have 200 million barrels of oil a year being transited across some of our most sensitive offshore areas. It seems to me that Greenpeace has taken an extraordinarily stupid attitude in relation to these issues. I suspect strongly that Greenpeace's recent activities in relation to the seismic surveying of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd in the Otway Basin have on balance lost it public support because for the first time Greenpeace has been forced publicly to shift its ground and has been exposed for what I consider to be misleading the public in relation to these issues.

I conclude by addressing the issue of compensation which was also raised by the Leader of the National Party. I preface my remarks by repeating the results of the Robinson survey, which gives Australia a very high order of priority in world terms-No. 4-as the most desirable country for oil and gas--

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that because of the Gulf war?

—No, it was unrelated to that; it was related to the desirability, taking into account all issues, of Australia as a target for international investment dollars. I will be happy to send a copy of the survey to the Leader of the National Party because I think that in a bipartisan sense everyone in this House would agree that, where we have a good story to tell, we should not diminish it by painting a gloomy picture.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the issue of compensation, I take the opportunity to congratulate Chevron, which voluntarily gave up its exploration lease in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. I think that Chevron's action ought to be acknowledged. It was a very public spirited response by Chevron, a company which has an enormous future in Australia in this area, and one which is, by any definition, a good corporate citizen.

Petroz NL, the other company referred to here, did not see itself as able to surrender its lease voluntarily. However, I make the point that exploration in the Great Barrier Reef has been inactive for two decades or so. Petroleum exploration in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park is prohibited under the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975, which I strongly support. In the context of compensation, the Government does not propose to compensate unless the termination of permit Q11P is found to be an acquisition of property within the meaning of section 51(xxxi) of the Constitution. If that is adjudicated upon and found in that way, obviously the Government would have to reconsider the matter.

The legal advice available to me and my clear recognition of constitutional law-albeit now going back some considerable time-leads me to the view that because the Commonwealth is gaining no benefit from terminating the permits, compensation does not and should not be an issue for the Government.
Mr Tim Fischer interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —If they take a different view from government, every company, whether it is Petroz, and every individual ought to have the right to test that in the courts. I seek neither to encourage nor discourage Petroz. Petroz is a good and exciting company too. I am certain that a slight difference of opinion on this issue will not impact on that company's contribution in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of other issues were raised by honourable members, but I do not think any of them are of sufficient moment to require me to respond to them. In relation to the Petroz issue, clearly it is incumbent upon governments to make judgments about competing interests. When we are talking about one of the seven natural wonders of the world-the Great Barrier Reef-I think the importance of that area overwhelms all other considerations.

There is a responsibility on government to ensure that not only now but also in the future we protect that very fragile ecosystem. That is why, when the public debate was on some time ago about whether the Government was allegedly going to allow exploration and production on the Great Barrier Reef, I watched with dismay. It was a classic example of how in this country misinformation on emotional issues can be badly distorted through the media.

I am sure that every member of this House would agree that our primary obligation is the protection of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. Indirectly, that is what this Bill intends to do, in part at least, and I am sure that before the bar of Australian public opinion that would find a very high degree of approval. DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991[COGNATE BILL:INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1991]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 February, on motion by Mr Willis:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: -I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 concurrently with the Industrial Relations Amendment Bill (No. 2). There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes the opportunity to debate the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 and the Industrial Relations Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991. I apologise to the House if my remarks are sometimes a little unclear. I have come unexpectedly to this debate from the dentist's chair, so the House might bear with me if I do not make sense on occasions.

SPEECH.PARA: This debate is an opportunity for the Opposition and other members of the House to say something about what is clearly lurking beneath the surface of the Government's industrial relations policy agenda; that is, the issue of the resurrection of the labour court proposal which was hastily buried in the lead-up to the 1987 election. You may think, Mr Deputy Speaker, that that is a fairly long bow to draw in a debate which, in relation to the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill, the first Bill we are considering, deals with a number of what can fairly be called machinery amendments to the Industrial Relations Act relating to a number of issues, including a shortening in the qualification period for people as potential appointees to the Remuneration Tribunal.

The Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) picks up, in substance, the recommendations of the Gleeson committee, which was established by the Government to resolve the undignified row that has broken out, and has gone on for several months, between the members of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and the members of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) over the effective breaking of the nexus between the presidential members of the Commission and judges of the Federal Court of Australia.

Mr Gleeson has come up with a recommendation which seeks, not surprisingly, given his brief, to be all things to all men and to satisfy both of the warring parties. However, the Government, in picking up that recommendation and inserting it in Amendment Bill (No. 2), has in part anticipated the establishment of a labour court or a separate industrial division of the Federal Court. And, of course, the Opposition has profound objections to the establishment of a labour court.

I did not lament the breaking of the nexus between the salary and remuneration of presidential members of the Commission and judges of the Federal Court because I do not regard-and nor does the Opposition-the Industrial Relations Commission as being a court. It has always appeared passing strange to me, since it was decided in the boilermakers case in 1956 that the then Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission could not exercise the judicial power of the Commonwealth, that we have in any way persisted with the notion that members of the Commission, either the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission or its successor, the Industrial Relations Commission, should have the status of judges. I do not say that out of disrespect to the members of the Commission. I do not suggest that they should not be properly remunerated. I simply do not accept that there should be an ongoing nexus between the remuneration of judges of the Federal Court and the remuneration of members of the Industrial Relations Commission, irrespective of the qualifications of members of the Industrial Relations Commission.

It is because Amendment Bill (No. 2) in part anticipates the establishment of a labour court that the Opposition will oppose the Bill in this House and it will be opposed in the other place, on the assumption that the Government, with its numbers, will put the Bill through this House. I want therefore to spend the time available in this debate to say something about the issue of a labour court. There is no doubt that the Government has worked very hard to win the support of the Australian Democrats to move to take away the common law remedies now available to employers and the very effective remedies made available under sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act.

I want to take the House back to 1987, when the current Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) introduced an industrial relations Bill that was very largely based on the recommendations of the Hancock Committee of Review of the Australian Industrial Relations Laws and Systems. In 1987 the Government proposed to establish a Commonwealth labour court. That Commonwealth labour court would have been under the jurisdiction, in a ministerial sense-if I can put it that way-not of the Attorney-General but of the Minister for Industrial Relations.

That court would not have been able to apply the remedies under sections 45d and 45e without a number of preconditions being fulfilled. Those preconditions essentially involved the parties to a dispute being required to go before the Industrial Relations Commission to see whether their dispute could be settled by means of conciliation before they would have the legal right to invoke the protection of the Trade Practices Act or, indeed, the available common law remedies.

Apologists for the labour court could well say, `What is wrong with that?'. What is wrong with that proposal is that, if it were implemented, it would destroy the most effective element of section 45d of the Trade Practices Act. That most essential element is the capacity of a party that is at the sharp end of predatory union conduct, which is destroying that party's business, to go immediately to a Federal Court judge and obtain an injunction from the Federal Court ordering the union in question to stop destroying the person's business and to lift the boycott that has been placed on that business.

If the 1987 design pattern for the labour court were ever to become the law of Australia, then that immediate remedy under section 45d of getting an injunction-telling a union to stop wrecking somebody's business-would no longer be available. A businessman in that situation-that is, the situation envisaged by the 1987 design-would be forced to go to the Industrial Relations Commission. There would be two or three weeks of mindless jawboning and in the process he would be bled white, his business would go and he would be forced to capitulate in order to save his business. That is why the Opposition will never support a proposal to establish a labour court. We will never support a proposal to take away from the ordinary courts of Australia the power to administer not only the common law remedies that are available but also the very effective weapon that has been available under the Trade Practices Act since 1977.

The union movement in this country is very fond of talking about the hard-won gains of the past. I do not take any umbrage at that. There were gains that needed to be won by employees in this country. I do not refer to that particular endearing phrase of the union movement in any pejorative sense. If I were the President of the ACTU I would talk about hard-won gains and I would remind my dwindling membership of what the union movement had been able to achieve in the past.

It is not only Martin Ferguson and Bill Kelty who have hard-won gains in Australia's industrial relations debate. I regard section 45d and the establishment of common law remedies as being a hard-won gain of those in the Australian community who have fought very hard over the last five or 10 years to bring about a reformed industrial relations system. It is only five years ago that Professor Hancock, George Polites and Charlie Fitzgibbon comprised the membership. All of them in their different ways were very eminent people in the industrial relations scene in Australia. On some issues I would not find myself agreeing with all of them, although I might agree with some of them on some occasions on some issues.

I seem to recall, incidentally, that back in 1985 Charlie Fitzgibbon wrote a very erudite paper on the value of enterprise bargaining. I do not think it got a very warm reception from the current Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) or from the then Minister for Industrial Relations because it was a bit ahead of its time. In fact, it was almost dangerously New Right in some of the terminology that it used.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Will the Treasurer please advise the House of the economic implications of the March quarter consumer price index (CPI) released today?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The CPI inflation in this quarter was in the negative. We were actually deflating in the quarter by 0.2 per cent. The result was that over the course of the year the inflation rate came down to this low number of 4.9 per cent, compared with 6.9 per cent for the year to December-a 2 percentage point change in the quarter. It puts beyond doubt the Government's belief that Australia is to have an historic victory on inflation and it is, without doubt, the best number of fundamental economic significance in two decades.

ANSWER.PARA: It is the most profound sign that Australia is entering the 1990s with a transformed economy, a low inflationary economy. It is the first negative quarter since December 1963. It is the largest quarterly fall since December 1961. It demonstrates that the Government's policy-which has been to deal with inflation via monetary policy, fiscal policy and wages policy-has been successful and that the rise in inflation to nearly 10 per cent stemming from the fall in the exchange rate in the middle 1980s has now been dealt with and that inflation has now come down in a trend way, along with inflationary expectations, to be at the level of our trading partners and, as the Prime Minister said, well below the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development average.

Not only that: in the quarter in which we are now living, we have seen falling petrol prices, we have got virtually no wage increases coming through the system-very small wage increases coming through the system-and we have further falls in mortgage interest rates, which augurs well for a low June quarter CPI. By way of illustration, if the CPI for the June quarter were to be positive by half a percentage point, the annual inflation rate would fall to 3.8 per cent. In this quarter, if the CPI ends up being around 0.5 per cent, inflation will have fallen to around 3.8 per cent, but for the moment it is 4.9 per cent-under 5 per cent-the lowest quarter for the first time since 1961.

This means a great deal to the economy. It means that we are entering the 1990s with a transformed economy. It means that we have got over the hurdle of inflation, which our opponents opposite were never able to do. It means that no longer will we have our competitiveness leaching away by three or four percentage points a year, against our export competing and import competing industries. It means that Australia is not fated to have high nominal rates of interest into the future, as there is a capacity to bring interest rates down--

TALK.START.PARA: —Real rates?

That is the dividend of being successful. It is those lower nominal and potentially real rates of interest which will lower the cost of capital to Australian business and which will spur investment on through the 1990s; and it is that investment and that growth which will pull down unemployment and give us a low inflationary, prosperous economy as we continue to lift these export volumes, which I spoke of at length yesterday, and start to bring to fruition the picture I painted yesterday of rising exports through the 1990s--
—It's a gloomy picture.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. In my electorate of Hunter and in other coal producing electorates the coalminers-magnificent men all-are making strenuous efforts to try to improve occupational health and safety. Can the Minister outline to the House the areas of concern to the Government and how the Government is ensuring that standards of occupational health and safety are maintained and improved in Australia's major export industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, as we all know, coal is now our No. 1 export industry. Exports in the year ahead are expected to be around $6.3 billion. That is an increase of about 17 per cent since 1985-86. Coalmining, by its very nature, is a very difficult and very dangerous task. Figures for the honourable member's area, for example, show that since 1965 there have been 41 deaths because of roof fall alone in the Newcastle and South Maitland districts. Of these, 24 occurred in the great northern seam. If we look at the total deaths and other statistics from 1980, we see that these numbered 53 in the northern district and seven deaths in the great northern seam. ANSWER.PARA: The interests of the honourable member and of coal workers in maintaining and improving standards of occupational health and safety are mine and those of the Government. In 1989-90, man shifts lost as a result of illness or accident totalled some 278,000, or 67 per cent of total man shifts lost. In underground mines, about 220,000 man shifts were lost.

In the case of underground mines, pneumoconiosis-more commonly known as dusting-has been of particular concern. In 1946, pneumoconiosis was prevalent among coalminers, affecting about 20 per cent. They have all been very instrumental in reducing this level of the occurrence of pneumoconiosis.

Honourable members would be right to wonder whether the 0.7 per cent was still too high and what the implications would be if we expand underground mining operations further. The Commonwealth Government is committed to seeing that standards are maintained and improved, and we acknowledge the pivotal role of the Joint Coal Board in this issue.

The honourable member for Hunter also mentioned occupational safety, and I have given some statistics about the whole problem of roof fall. It is fair to say that the examples of wind blast and roof fall are relatively low, but it is very important to understand the factors that contribute to this. It is to the full credit of the JCB that a research and development effort is now under way to fully investigate the causes and to determine appropriate remedial action. The efforts which the various players-the JCB, the unions and the companies-have made, resulting in improved working conditions, stand to their credit.

In summary, there is an ideological belief that we can scrap the JCB and all the work that has been done in this area. That would only represent a trashing of the progress that has been made. This is following a paragraph which says:

ANSWER.PARA: It is absolutely essential that the Reserve Bank be free of political interference to be able to implement monetary policies in a sustainable, consistent and transparent manner.

The implication of that sentence is that the Board is politically interfered with and that the operation of its duties is not transparent, not consistent and not sustainable. I want to quote some things from the Reserve Bank Act to put some of this matter in context. Section 10 (2) says:

It is the duty of the Board, within the limits of its powers, to ensure that the monetary and banking policy of the Bank is directed to the greatest advantage of the people of Australia and that the powers of the Bank under this Act, the `Banking Act' 1959 and the regulations under that Act are exercised in such a manner as, in the opinion of the Board, will best contribute to-
(a) the stability of the currency of Australia;
(b) the maintenance of full employment in Australia; and
(c) the economic prosperity and welfare of the people of Australia.

In other words, that section means that the primary responsibility of the Board is to do what it thinks is right-`in the opinion of the Board'. In other words, the implication in the sentence which the Leader of the Opposition has in his press statement is that those Board members have breached that section, and that they have done things which, in their opinion, are not best to contribute to these factors. That is the first point. The second point is in section 11, which reads:
(1) The Board shall, from time to time, inform the Government of the monetary and banking policy of the bank.

(2) In the event of a difference of opinion between the Government and the Board whether that policy is directed to the greatest advantage of the people of Australia, the Treasurer and the Board shall endeavour to reach agreement.

So the drafters of the Act require the Treasurer and the Board to endeavour to reach agreement. It is a requirement of an Act of parliament that I and the Board, in this case, endeavour to reach agreement on monetary policy. I have had, of course, no difficulties whatsoever in that respect. It goes on to say:

(3) If the Treasurer and the Board are unable to reach agreement, the Board shall forthwith furnish to the Treasurer a statement in relation to the matter in respect of which the difference of opinion has arisen.
Finally, it says:

(4) The Treasurer may then submit a recommendation to the Governor-General, and the Governor-General, acting with the advice of the Federal Executive Council, may, by order, determine the policy to be adopted by the Bank.
That is, the Governor-General, acting on the advice of the Federal Executive Council, may determine the policy of the Board of the Reserve Bank of Australia upon advice from the Treasurer.

So it states that, in the end, the elected government-the elected body of the Commonwealth-should decide monetary policy and the effects it is going to have on the great populace of Australia. What more democratic notion could one conceive than that, notwithstanding the board's best endeavours-its primary responsibility to do what it thinks is right-in the event of a disagreement, the Treasurer consults the Governor-General through the Executive Council? What more democratic and sensible process can there be, which is obviously comprehended by the drafters of these sections?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.

ANSWER.PARA: The discussion paper made clear that the reconciliation process was to be accompanied by a national commitment to address areas of Aboriginal disadvantage as a national objective leading to the centenary of the Australian Federation. I am pleased to report to the House that the result of these consultations has been extremely heartening and, might I say, deeply moving. Support has been given by Aboriginal community organisations and organisations such as the Central Land Council, the National Coalition of Aboriginal Organisations, the Queensland Aboriginal Coordinating Council, the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation, the Torres Strait Islander Advisory Board and the Uniting Aboriginal and Islander Christian Congress.

ANSWER.PARA: Letters have also come from State Premiers and from the Chief Minister of the Australian Capital Territory. . . . political leaders use their best endeavours to ensure bi-partisan public support for the process of reconciliation and that the urgency and necessity of the process be acknowledged.

The letter indicates that the Opposition has some concerns about the proposal but that the possibility exists for all sides of politics to go forward together for the benefit of Aboriginal people. I believe that the Government's plans for the process will address the Opposition's concerns. I have repeatedly said that there can be no reconciliation without justice, and therefore welcome the Opposition's support for a close monitoring of the success of government programs to address Aboriginal disadvantage. I highlight the important role by State and local governments in addressing that disadvantage.

I particularly welcome the Opposition's view that the work of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation should be focused at the grassroots and community level. It is absolutely essential that all sections of the Australian population be involved in this reconciliation process. The Opposition is quite right to highlight the need for consultation with both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians for the reconciliation process to succeed. I can assure the Opposition, and, indeed, all Australians, that consultation will be the hallmark of the reconciliation process.

The Government has always firmly intended that the process would involve practical benefits for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, and this has been supported by the Opposition. The Government has also made it clear that the focus of the process would be the process itself and not on any possible outcome. Indeed, the words of the Royal Commissioner, endorsed by the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), echo the words of the Prime Minister and myself in relation to the reconciliation process. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need for the Government to set a target for inflation that will achieve and maintain price stability.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The latest consumer price index figure is a good figure, and I welcome it. It is better than market expectations and a bit better than expectations in general. It means that Australia's inflation rate has dropped from 6.9 per cent to 4.9 per cent. I am sorry that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is not in here to debate the issues because one of the reasons that we have initiated this debate is to take the debate to the Government. He has been crowing about it-read his press release: an historic conquering of inflation by the world's greatest Treasurer-but the truth of the matter is that I do not believe the 4.9 per cent is nearly low enough. Furthermore, I do not believe we have reason to expect that it will stay down other than for the period of recession.

SPEECH.PARA: It will not surprise people to hear that, in a sense, the Treasurer exaggerates the figures. That has been the hallmark of his career for many years. If we take out the effects of mortgage costs and petrol prices, then the minus 0.2 per cent actually would be 1.2 per cent and the annual inflation rate would be 5.8 per cent; but that is still an improvement, from 6.9 per cent to 5.8 per cent. There is no doubt that it could well go lower: it will go lower as unemployment rises, as the scorched earth policy which this Government has introduced continues to wreak its damage on the Australian electorate.

Inflation always subsides as a consequence of a recession. Here we have the patient lying on the operating table. Yes, the Government has got the blood pressure down, but further surgery is still required. Yes, it has got the blood pressure down, but I ask the Treasurer: so what? Part of his defence is that he says that it did not happen in the last recession-blaming it all on the last Government. But in 1984 inflation actually fell to 3.9 per cent. It actually fell. We have been in the position we are in today before, with a low quarterly inflation figure. It fell dramatically in the Great Depression, and of course it came up again afterwards. Back in 1961 we had that short, sharp credit squeeze. I hope the political point is not lost on the Government. The Menzies Government nearly lost office; it stayed in office only as a result of the preferences of a communist, I think in Jim Killen's seat. So the electorate will certainly wreak its revenge upon the Government at the next election. In 1961 inflation fell. It was a very short, sharp contraction at that time, and inflation fell as a result of that sharply contracting economy.

None of that is really surprising. The only thing that is surprising is that these blokes get up here in Question Time and try to deny the obvious. Inflation is the consequence of excess demand chasing limited supply, and higher interest rates are certainly very effective in crushing demand, both consumption and investment, as I think most people now realise as they look around and see the Australian economy literally being destroyed brick by brick as a result of high interest rates. Not only does it destroy our manufacturing base but, as well, for our great exporters it makes the dollar higher than perhaps it otherwise would be. It makes it hard for us to export and easy for us to import-the two things that, of course, drive that massive current account deficit problem that we have.

The Government has done exactly what it promised at the last election not to do; that is, it has run a scorched earth policy. It is indisputable that Australia has an appalling record on inflation. This applies not just to recent years; basically it goes back 20 years, to the 1970s. As one of my backbench colleagues has said, it goes back to the Whitlam years, as so many things do. In the 1970s, inflation averaged 9.4 per cent, and in the 1980s it averaged 8.7 per cent.

It is also indisputable that the economic and social costs of high inflation are very great. I shall not dwell on that point, because I think that even the Government spokesmen in this debate would acknowledge the huge costs of inflation. It robs people of their savings. It discourages savings. It is theft. It discourages productive investment and it wastes a lot of time and effort as people put their resources into trying to hedge against it.

It distorts investment patterns. In fact we have seen that in recent years. The Treasurer boasts of the big increase in investments through the late 1980s, but we must ask ourselves: where has that investment gone? Has it gone into factories making widgets to help our export performance or to replace imports? No, it has not. It has gone, as it always has in recent years, into unproductive investments. We have had a building and housing boom, which is so typical of the Australian economy.

Welcome though it is, today's figure is simply not good enough, and I urge the Treasurer, when he responds, to put aside self-congratulation. He should stop patting himself on the back, telling us how he has conquered inflation, and at least acknowledge that 4.9 per cent is not good enough. Secondly, my view is that the figure is not sustainable, and I have very good reasons for taking that view. In fact, I have seven reasons. First, this Government has never had a real commitment to tackling inflation. We can go back to 1982 and see a classic from the Treasurer. In fact, the longer he is in office, the more pleasure we take from reading some of the things he has said in the past. In 1982, he said:
So, fighting inflation first (as a policy) is, frankly, a failure and we've gotta ditch it.

So he started as Treasurer without any commitment to fighting inflation. He has only found a commitment to fighting it now because he got a lucky break in September, which he grabbed with both hands. He knew the recession was coming; he knew inflation would come down as a result of it; and he wanted to ride in on its back. If one goes back to the last Budget, one finds that inflation was not the principal target; it was the current account deficit.

Secondly, the Government has publicly abandoned any specific targets for inflation. We had evidence of that again today when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was twice asked a very simple question-just a yes or no question-during Question Time. It was along the lines of, `You reckon you have inflation licked; give us a guarantee it will not go over 4.9 per cent'. That was a very simple question, but the Prime Minister failed the test absolutely miserably. And no wonder. The bloke he relies on-Mr Miller, who, the Prime Minister told us, is a good economist who used to work for the Treasurer and now works for one of the best firms in the country and is a good bloke, when reflecting opinion among many economists predicted that inflation will go up to the June quarter 1992.

The Government has never had a real commitment to attacking inflation; in fact, it has abandoned targets for inflation. Why is that? If one wants to see what the decisions of these guys are based on, one only has to look at the most recent poll. The Government says that it is not attacking inflation because there is no constituency to tackle inflation and it is not prepared to wear what it sees as the electoral costs of it.

The third reason I am not confident is simply this: the public has seen inflation come down before. As I said, back in 1984 it was 3.9 per cent. For years this Government has peppered us with false claims about its success over inflation. Honourable members may remember this classic promise made in 1988, when the Treasurer said that the Government's policies:
. . . will secure for Australia an inflation rate of 3 to 4 per cent in 1990.
Another one of his promises about lower inflation. I have another, which goes back a bit further to 1985 and is a classic Keating quote:
Inflation has been licked, we've got inflation back to the OECD average.

Does that not remind honourable members of what they heard half an hour ago? The Treasurer used virtually the same words. As a result, the Government has no credibility on the issue. That is very important because if we are to get inflation down, to keep it down and to minimise the costs, it is well recognised that having a government with credibility on inflation is a key part of that agenda.

Fourthly, I do not believe the Treasurer for the simple reason that the Government has no commitment to secure the fundamental changes that could assure this country that we could really lock in the gains. Again, it has been paraded before the House today in respect of the Reserve Bank of Australia. During Question Time this Treasurer talked about the Reserve Bank and its independence, but let us look at the public record. Do honourable members recall the Treasurer's Placido Domingo remark in that private chat to a couple of hundred journalists at the National Press Club? On that occasion he said:
. . . Leadership is about getting people into your pocket. . . . [I have] Treasury in my pocket, the Reserve Bank in my pocket, the financial community . . . both here and overseas, in my pocket.
That was not the first time he said that. In February 1989 a journalist asked him:
If your opinion is that monetary policy should be eased and you tell that to the Reserve Bank, surely they will be implementing otherwise . . . ?
Mr Keating replied:
No, but we don't have conflicts. I have been operating monetary policy with the Reserve Bank now for 7 years and I only instance the remarks of the ongoing government to underline that.

There is no question about it; this is the man who said he has them in his pocket. He is Placido Domingo to some but Placebo Drongo to others. If inflation comes about through demand being in excess of supply, one side of the solution is to boost the supply of goods and services. What do we need to boost supply? We need higher investment and productivity through industrial relations reforms and all the micro reforms that have been waiting on the back burner for the past five years. And, of course, yesterday was the anniversary of the Treasurer's `banana republic' statement.

Why am I am not confident? This Government has sown the seeds of higher inflation in the times ahead. The Government did that deal before the last election-accord mark 6-when it was then talking about a soft landing; it did a deal with the wharfies; and it went back to Whitlam, and it has the Public Service pacesetting again on wages. No wonder people question whether the Government really has a commitment to controlling inflation.

Lastly, because of all these things the Government has gone nowhere in breaking inflationary expectations. The market thinks inflation is coming down, sure-and the Government has lots of quotes to support that-but the market also thinks inflation is going to go up.
The truth is that we must get some structural changes. The Treasurer says that he has won game, set and match. I say to him, `We are going to win the rubber, and that is the rub for you'.

The changes to tackle inflation will have to be extensive. Firstly, the incoming government will have an unshakeable commitment to beating inflation. Secondly, we will set a clear target for eradicating inflation. One cannot be a little bit pregnant, as honourable members opposite want to be. Most commentators accept that a target of nought to 2 per cent, as set today by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), is a realistic one.

Thirdly, we will secure real independence for the Reserve Bank by amending the Reserve Bank Act 1959. I have already prepared a first draft, which will be an exposure draft in due course, of the amendments on which we will seek comment, and which we will eventually introduce. The legislation will establish a new charter for the Reserve Bank with price stability, beating inflation or taking on inflation as its principal objectives.

I think we ought to take the Secretary to the Treasury off the Reserve Bank, not to break entirely the links between the Government and the Reserve Bank-obviously those links will continue-but to mark the independence of that institution. We will require the Governor or an appropriate person from the Reserve Bank, a couple of times a year, to turn up before the Parliament to report on the bank's efforts to tackle inflation. We will also provide for the establishment of the Government's inflation target. There are three objectives-a commitment, a target and amendments to the Act.

Fourthly, of course, we will develop between the bank and the Government the concept of an employment contract where the Government specifies the inflation target and, critically, the necessary and complementary economic strategy from government to achieve the target. We will put together a broad economic package within which that fits.

High on our list of priorities must be industrial relations reform. It is absolutely critical to the implementation of our policies. We will have a structurally tighter fiscal policy so that we can reweight and rechange the mix and the stance of Government policy as it is today.

We will move ahead with privatisation-not the Mickey Mouse 30 per cent of some bank, but real privatisation. We will have genuine waterfront reforms, shipping reforms, taxation reforms-which are another critical part of our early legislative package-communication reforms and tariffs. These changes are radical, but only for Australia. Quite frankly the Treasurer will say that it is naive and that it is quackery. If the Treasurer were to look at the rest of the world he would see that most of these changes have already been introduced.

The Prime Minister failed to give us a pledge. It was a pretty simple question: will you give us a guarantee that inflation will not go over 4.9 per cent? I ask the Treasurer to give us a simple answer-yes or no-to the question. Will the Treasurer give that pledge? The whole Parliament awaits his reply.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand that the Opposition is politically smarting under the number which the Australian Statistician has published today, because it is the lowest quarterly negative fall in inflation in the consumer price index since December 1961. That is a generation ago-30 years ago. It is the first negative quarter since December 1963. It is there for trend reasons, as the Opposition knows. It is not just a flash in the pan; it is there because the Government engineered inflation down with wage tax trade-offs through 1988 and 1989, and it had the wages and nominal wage discipline which has come through the processes of the accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

SPEECH.PARA: It burns right into members of the Opposition that such a result can be produced in cooperation-not by bashing people, abusing unionists, putting out nasty press statements or by trying to use central banks to do things which they know they were never designed to do.

It galls them to think that a cooperative process can actually reduce inflation. In this Budget we have an average weekly earnings target of 7 per cent. This year we will bring wages in at about 5.1 per cent against the target of 7 per cent. That is the reason.

There is no doubt, as I said at Question Time, that today's result puts beyond doubt the Government's belief that Australia is to have an historic victory over inflation. I repeat what I said then: it is the best number of fundamental economic significance that we have seen in two decades. It is the most profound sign that Australia is entering the 1990s with a low inflationary economy, a transformed economy, which will prove to Australians and others that Australia is not fated to have permanently high inflation and high interest rates. That means that as Australia joins the low inflation countries again it does so with the belief in the minds of many that inflationary expectations are down.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), in his very ordinary address was hinting that this was a flash in the pan. He said that we had had a bit of luck in the September quarter and that, while the markets think inflation is down, the public does not. That is not true. I passed over to him the table of inflationary expectations from that survey conducted by the Australian Statistician, which shows that the nation believes and expects inflation to come down and that inflationary expectations are coming down. That is the most important thing-not just that there is a low number but that people expect it to be low and they expect to see inflation declining over the period.

For Australia this means that we will not go on as we did in the 1970s and 1980s, with our inflation rate leaching our competitiveness by four or five percentage points a year and the adjustment having to come via the exchange rate, which is inflationary, which drives up the stock of Australian denominated debt, which makes our nation poorer in world terms, which cuts the values of Australian assets in world terms. Now that we have an inflation rate at that of our trading partners, below the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development average, and with the prospect of its falling further in the June quarter, with that kind of scenario we have the capacity to keep our competitiveness together and to trade our way successfully into the 1990s.

Yesterday I referred to the quarterly accounts of the Statistician in relation to exports. I gave the statistics on the strong export growth through the 1980s. We have had phenomenal export growth through the 1980s. Yesterday I was discussing with my advisers some of the largest categories of manufactured export performance, and the largest category was `Miscellaneous'. It was not a big petrochemical project or liquefied natural gas project. `Miscellaneous' includes all sorts of things-hot water heaters, air-conditioners, taps-as the nation responds to the internationalisation of Australia, as it responds to this new found competitiveness. That is why our manufactured exports are growing, as they have grown in the 1980s and will grow in the 1990s.

As I said yesterday, if we had even halfway decent terms of trade we would be running a current account deficit with a debt stable now at 2.5 per cent or 2.75 per cent of gross domestic product. If the debt is stable now, it means that we end up running merchandise trade surpluses through the 1990s. Sure, we have a problem to deal with the stock of accumulated debt, but we are dealing with that $100 billion of accumulated private debt by, in the first instance, putting $60 billion worth of assets offshore, to countervail that debt onshore with private assets offshore. If we regard that as the price we have paid for the indolence of our past in the 1960s and 1970s but in the future, from here on, we run a merchandise trade and services surplus and have a low inflation rate with a lower cost of capital, lower nominal interest rates and, possibly, lower real interest rates, which then fuels, with a high profit share, a stronger rate of investment in those export industries, what prospect does the 1990s hold? A good prospect.

TALK.START.PARA: —On that theory, when will the net income deficit start to turn around?
—I think that is starting now.
—There is not much evidence.
—I think the honourable member for Bennelong will find that it is starting now.
—It is a valid question.

—It is. I saw an article recently where Gary Pemberton of Brambles said, `We are just now learning to bring dividends home'. One of the reasons we did not bring dividends home was that we had a foreign tax credit system. We have abolished the foreign tax credit system by putting a foreign source income system in place, which means that now one can distribute from a company in North America or Britain back to Australia without worrying about needing to top up tax under a foreign tax credit system, and that distribution will countervail the net income deficit that the honourable member for Bennelong speaks about with the interest payments going offshore.

SPEECH.PARA: The most important thing is that we are not adding to the debt at source from our trading goods and services. Last month's balance of payments shows that we are running a goods and services surplus. If we can run a goods and services surplus, that is, pay for all the goods and services we buy from the world, into the 1990s-and from now on we are running a trade surplus which is cutting that debt-our problem then is to attend to the debt of the past, not to be adding any into the future. With that low inflation rate and a structural surplus of this variety, a structural Budget surplus and occupational superannuation pumping 3 or 4 per cent of GDP a year into savings, Australia's savings imbalance must change and the current account deficit must come down.

If the current account deficit comes down with a low inflation rate, lower interest rates, better cost of capital, more investment, more product, more exports, more import competing products and a larger surplus, we join that virtuous circle where Australia once and for all gets out of the shocking period when we believed we could take our benefits and our living standards from a tariff wall. We will get away from that dismal legacy where we thought we could progress ourselves by cutting ourselves off from the rest of the world.

That is what these years are about; they are about that transition. In the transition the party got overheated in 1988-89 and the Government had to take the punchbowl away. We have done that for the greater good of Australians-to give them that period into the 1990s of low inflationary growth so that the transition that we started and undertook in 1983-84 will be a transition we successfully complete.

I do not have the slightest doubt that we are now going through this fundamental transition. We are doing it successfully as our export sector, our external sector, picks up the slack and starts to really make the pace. I have no doubt that the transition we began in 1983-84 is well and truly on the way. We have had the problem of the globalisation of markets in the 1980s, of the growth in credit in nearly all of the economies around us, and we are now seeing recessions as a result, not just in Australia but in Britain, Canada, and the United States, and a slowdown in Japan for exactly the same reason-inflated asset prices and too much credit growth by the financial system with the globalisation of markets. That is behind the lot of us.

The low inflationary period that dragged the United States along in a low inflationary environment, which Paul Volker gave to it in 1980 by a recession of this very variety, is one which we will keep as we rebalance ourselves and find that credit markets start behaving sensibly and ration resources properly. If credit markets are free, as we have in a deregulated financial system, and they are rationing resources correctly and sensibly, there are, for a start, more resources to ration because the Government has cut its call on savings by $30,000m a year by cutting government spending and there is a structural Budget surplus.

We have seen those changes and the savings coming through the superannuation system and more corporate savings. With dividend imputation we allow companies to save, whereas the coalition governments taxed dividends at 78c in the dollar. We are now taxing them at 39c if they do not distribute and at 47c if they do. We have cut the effective rate on tax and distributed income from 78c to 39c, or 47c if they distribute personally. That means that the middle size corporate sector can save for the first time in our history. It is those savings which will give Australia a decent sized medium corporate sector, which the United States has but we have never had. We have had little companies, small businesses or large companies. There has been very little in between.

That is why it is important that that big category of merchandise exports is `miscellaneous' from all quarters of the economy-no particular description-and from all these businesses, which are now finding that clever ideas can be sold abroad, that they do not need to simply build major billion dollar projects to do any good, and that we are actually getting this quantum change.

This is the 1990s. I am quite certain that we will make it. There is no problem with that. As I said yesterday, the only problem for the Government is that we want to be around to see our work come to fruition. We want to be here to enjoy the creativity. The honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) is trying to interject, but he knows that his Party could never have put this together. The Opposition would not have put together the agreed incomes approach under the accord. It would not have taken the risks we took with the floating of the spot rate and the exchange rate and the removal of exchange controls, or the absolutely revolutionary change to dividend imputation and the change to occupational superannuation.

These are path breaking. We have done this in a way in which we have pulled the weaker people in society along with us. We did not say, `Oh, look, only the strong people get the prizes here'. We said, `That is not a goer. We want kids in school. We want kids from working class backgrounds to get a decent education. We want to see the poor looked after and low income families receiving benefits such as the family allowance supplement. We want to look after the health of all Australians. If a member of a family of six wakes up sick, sore and sorry, that person will be covered for health purposes. That person will be protected under Medicare'. We have tried to bind society together while we have made these changes with the cooperation of the trade union movement.

Bashing people, confronting them, butting them, doing all the things that conservative governments tend to do, does not produce that kind of society. A cohesive society gives more manageable economic outcomes. We have proven that today with this inflation rate. Those more manageable economic outcomes have, during the 1980s, given us three times the rate of employment growth of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development.

Sure, at the moment we have fallen on hard times in terms of employment. But we will get those jobs back. When we get them back we will keep, as we have to date, the 1.5 million jobs that we have created since 1983-84. Those are the prospects for Australia. I want them to be the prospects for Labor, not the prospects for a collection of individuals in parties which, frankly, never had the wit, the creativity or the courage to construct such a sophisticated model. They never worked with the departments; they never worked with the bureaucracy; they never worked with the central bank; and they never worked with the Treasury. They always believed that the bureaucrats were trying to cheat them. They spent two years booting the guts out of the bureaucracy after they lost office, as though it was its fault.

We have done it by bringing these institutions together and by taking our cue from the labour movement-by being faithful to the precepts of our own Party; not by running off with some alien philosophy but by trying to marry a compassionate policy with an economically efficient economy and, in doing so, knowing that that is where we are producing wealth and employment.

That is why we are faithful to our Party's creed to look after the poor, to see that people get a share of growth and to have a fairer society. That is why we get the cooperation of the unions; that is why the inflation rate is down; and that is why we are entitled to run Australia in the 1990s. I know that those opposite are going to try to stop us. But they will not. We will beat them again. The truth, as I have said here before, is that we are better. We are better because we have thought about it, our heart is in the right place. And not only that: our head is there to match it.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF COMPUTER CENTRE FOR THE AUSTRALIAN CUSTOMS SERVICE, BRUCE, AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEDDALL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business and Customs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Purpose built computer centre for Australian Customs Service, Bruce, ACT.

The proposed work recommended by the Standing Committee on Public Works involves the construction of a purpose built computer centre for the Australian Customs Service at Bruce in the Australian Capital Territory. Work will involve the construction of a two-storey building of approximately 3,780 square metres of gross floor area, provision for parking facilities for 30 cars, landscaping and associated site works and services. The computer mainframe is to be located in the upper floor, while plant, loading dock, storage, staff amenities and minimal office accommodation will be located on the ground floor level. It is anticipated that construction will commence in June 1991 with the work to be completed by December 1992. The project will employ about 150 workers at the peak of the construction activity.

The proposal was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works in November 1990. The Committee tabled its report on 14 May 1991 recommending construction of the building at a limited cost estimated at $16.9m at November 1990 prices. The Australian Customs Service and property services program have noted all the Committee's recommendations. However, despite their support for the project, some of the issues raised require comment-and I acknowledge in the Parliament the Chairman of the Public Works Committee, the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis).

The site selected for the Australian Customs Service computer centre is adjacent to the site for the Australian Taxation Office computer centre at Bruce in the Australian Capital Territory. The reasons for the two computer centres not having been combined and developed as a single project are: firstly, that the Australian Taxation Office requirements for new computer facilities were developed in 1988-89, and were examined by the Government and approved as part of the 1989 Budget process, while the Australian Customs Service requirements were developed in 1990, and examined and approved as part of the 1990 Budget process. Secondly, after examination by the Public Works Committee of the possibility of combining the two projects, it was concluded that this option would be more costly during the design and construction phase and that it would impose significant delays, especially on the Australian Taxation Office project, thus resulting in the reduced efficiency of revenue collection functions. Both clients are attracted to having separate computer facilities for reasons of individual security requirements rather than being in favour of any proposal for collocation.

In providing a solution for the two separate facilities, Australian Construction Services has carried out the instructions of its client departments. As a result of the concern that two similar buildings could be built next door to each other, the Committee recommended that the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) carry out a review of Commonwealth departments and authorities to ensure that, as far as practicable, facilities such as computer installations are collocated. This recommendation, incidentally, is currently being considered.

However, the issue of coordination of future capital works projects needs to be considered in the context of the Department of Administrative Services no longer having an overall regulatory role. Each department or agency of the Commonwealth is now responsible for its own property in capital works. Nonetheless, given the Public Works Committee's recent comments, the Minister for Administrative Services has asked his Department to discuss with the Department of Finance ways to address the matters raised by the Public Works Committee for future capital works projects.

The Australian Capital Territory Electricity Commission and Water Authority insists that two independent electricity supplies be provided at the computer centre for part of their overall strategy to supply a high level of service and availability to the user. It also allows the Authority to undertake maintenance work on substations without undue disruption to client power supplies. The reason a back-up diesel generation unit is still required is that, as there is only one active power supply entering the building at any one time, in the event of a power failure it may take officers some time to manually energise the second supply, in which case, without the diesel generation unit, the building will have no power.

Finally, the Australian Customs Service will consider the fitting out of its existing computer facility located in the Edmund Barton building as a back-up facility for other Commonwealth departments and authorities, and it is planning the refurbishment of that site. I thank the Committee for its report and commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall), who I know is representing his colleague in another place, has not given the Parliament adequate responses to the matters raised by the Standing Committee on Public Works and, in particular, the Chairman, the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), when he presented his report here yesterday. In fact, I think we are seeing very much a case of the Yes, Minister syndrome, where the Parliament is being treated with a certain amount of contempt.

SPEECH.PARA: There were some very grave concerns raised by the Public Works Committee yesterday and by the Chairman when he presented his report: about the way the Department of Administrative Services has been operating over this whole matter; about the way the Minister has been operating; and, probably most importantly, about the accountability of this Department to the Parliament.

I do not believe that in putting forward this motion today the Government has taken on board the concerns of the Public Works Committee properly. It ought to be noted that it is rather rare for the Public Works Committee to bring up such grave concerns. The reservations that the Public Works Committee has brought up are worthy of considerably more work than bringing in the report one day and on the following day, without proper consideration of those concerns, debating the motion that the work proceed.

I think all honourable members ought to be aware that we have a rather ludicrous situation where there are two buildings side by side. As the Minister for Small Business and Customs tried to point out today, the decision to build one was a year ahead of the decision to build the other. But the buildings are side by side, both of them doing virtually identical things. It is just a nonsense. Yet it seems that the Department of Administrative Services is going to proceed as though everything is quite rosy, there is nothing more to explain, and the Public Works Committee has had its inquiry and raised a few concerns, but that is just tough.

The Minister has said, `The fact that this has occurred is being considered', as he has just pointed out, and the Department, through its Minister, will be looking at it for the future. I honestly believe that this is far from satisfactory and, from the point of view of accountability to the Parliament, I think that the Public Works Committee has every right to demand a much better response than that which has been given so far.

It is worth highlighting exactly what has happened. It was understood some years ago that both the Customs Office and the Australian Taxation Office were going to need these facilities. It was understood some time ago that it would save money to have a joint facility for their computer installations, so that there would be no need to have two buildings duplicating power supplies and all the various things that go with it. This was worked out years ago. However, apparently Customs fell a year behind.

The question is then raised: why was this allowed to happen? Why did not the Department and its Minister ensure that there was proper coordination? We are seeing what amounts to a waste of money. I do not accept the explanation given today by the Minister that it would have been more costly had the two been put under one roof. It certainly could not have been more costly if proper planning had been undertaken.

I draw attention to this matter because I do not think that we can afford this at the best of times, let alone right now when this country is in a very serious recession, probably the most serious recession we have seen in 60 years. It is just unacceptable that we are seeing what amounts to waste and duplication when it has been known for years that these facilities had to be built.

I will quote from the comments of the Chairman of the Public Works Committee. These same comments were read into the Senate Hansard by my Tasmanian colleague Senator Calvert. The points made have not been properly responded to. The honourable member for Throsby stated:

The Committee was of the view that substantial overall savings would have been made had both facilities been in the same building from the earliest planning stage. Accordingly, the Committee has recommended that the Minister for Administrative Services should conduct a review of all Commonwealth departments and authorities to ensure that, as far as practical, facilities such as computing installations are collocated.

It is just not adequate to move a motion the following day to the effect that the Government will go ahead irrespective. We believe that it would have been more costly. It seems that all the work, time and effort put in by the Public Works Committee has just been cast aside by the Minister who said, `My Department has told me it is probably a bit hard, therefore we will just ignore what the Public Works Committee has said'.

This is a very grave matter that cannot be brushed aside or swept under the carpet. It is a matter that the Public Works Committee ought to be bringing forward in a response to Parliament. It should demand to know why the Government is paying such lip-service to the very valuable work that it has been doing.

As the Public Works Committee has rightly observed, it seems that, when the two departments involved suggested that risks of industrial disputation and sabotage were an excuse for this decision not to have the joint facility, it fails to see how this risk is reduced by having two almost identical facilities right next to one another. The Public Works Committee has raised another question to which there has not been a satisfactory response, namely, why must there be a duplicate backup power supply when the two facilities are side by side? Again, to give a very brief response which seems to brush off the whole matter raised by the Committee is not satisfactory. The Committee deserves congratulations on having called on the ACT to look into better road works so that there would not be parking problems associated with this construction.

In conclusion, this whole process raises very serious concerns about the accountability to Parliament of the Department and the Minister. It raises very serious concerns about the work which has been so painstakingly done by the Public Works Committee and which just seems to have been overlooked. There are very serious concerns regarding the considerable wastage of public money through very poor planning.

We have two virtually identical facilities being built side by side. The best excuse that can be offered is that planning did not facilitate this; yet it was known five years ago that these two facilities would be needed and that they could be combined into one building. However, despite that knowledge, it has been overlooked. It is not satisfactory for the Minister to brush it aside and say, `There will be a review in the future and we may look at the Committee's recommendations'. I believe that the Parliament deserves and should expect a far better response from the Department and the Minister than it has been given today.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business and Customs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Construction of a Chancery and associated recreation facilities on approximately 8,000 square metres of land at Jalan Rasuna Said, Jakarta, Indonesia.
