PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Duffy, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
The Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) proposes amendments to a range of Acts dealing with Commonwealth criminal law. The most significant amendments are:

- those which amend the Passports Act 1938 and the Crimes Act 1914 to introduce an effective procedure to ensure that the existing scheme under which the passports of persons charged with, or convicted of, certain serious offences, particularly drug offences, may be surrendered; and

- those which amend the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988 to enable information obtained under that Act to be provided to a foreign law enforcement agency to which the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987 applies.

I shall briefly discuss each group of amendments proposed in the Bill. Part 2 contains several amendments to the Australian Federal Police Act 1979 (AFP Act). The first of these will considerably widen the scope of the witness protection scheme. It is in line with the Government's concern to provide the maximum protection possible to people who are under threat as a consequence of witnessing or being present at an event, or because of their relationship with such witnesses.

The amendment will remove any suggestion that witness protection arrangements apply only to people who have actually witnessed an event and are called to give evidence and not to their families who may be used as tools by the criminal element to orchestrate the witness's silence.

The second amendment will adapt the management initiated retirement scheme to overcome some practical difficulties. It allows compensation to be calculated after appointment where a determination was not validly made at the time of appointment to the AFP. Currently, a determination may only be made on appointment. It will also allow the Commissioner to end a person's appointment before the expiry of his or her term. Previously, the appointment could only be ended by the person who made the original appointment. This could create practical problems as the AFP employs over 3,000 people on terms of appointment from five to 10 years. It might therefore happen that the person making the original appointment was unavailable.

Parts 3 and 7 of the Bill amend the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988 (CTR Act) and make related amendments to the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987. Part 3 of the Bill contains a number of amendments to the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988. Many of these are of a minor nature and are intended to assist the Director of the Cash Transaction Reports Agency (CTRA) in the performance of his functions under the Act and clarify the position of cash dealers in relation to certain matters. For example, subsection 16 (1) of the CTR Act requires cash dealers to report to the CTRA those transactions which the cash dealer has reasonable grounds to suspect may be relevant to tax evasion, a Commonwealth offence or the enforcement of the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987. Subsection 16 (5) provides protection against legal proceedings for cash dealers and their employees in relation to any action taken pursuant to section 16.

Concern has been expressed that, unless all the requisite preconditions set out in subsection 16 (1) are strictly met, the cash dealer will not be able to claim the benefit of the protection against legal action contained in subsection 16 (5). For example, if a teller reports a particular transaction in the mistaken belief that it is relevant to tax evasion or to a Commonwealth offence and, after investigation, it is found to be relevant only to a State offence or to have an innocent explanation, no action should lie against the teller.

Other amendments implement the recommendations of the Group of Seven (G7) industrialised nations Financial Action Task Force on Money-Laundering. Although not a member of the G7, Australia was invited to participate in the task force when it was established in July 1989, because of the comprehensive nature of our anti-money laundering measures. The task force made 40 recommendations on anti-money laundering initiatives which relate to greater vigilance by financial institutions and increased cooperation with law enforcement agencies through initiatives such as suspect transaction reporting and consideration of import and export reporting and significant cash transaction reporting together with law enforcement initiatives such as confiscation of proceeds of crime and mutual assistance at all levels.

Australia meets most of the requirements of the G7 recommendations because of the provisions of the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987, the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987 and the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988 and associated changes in the practices and procedures of our financial institutions. There are, however, a number of recommendations which Australia must implement before achieving full compliance with the G7 recommendations. These include prohibiting cash dealers from disclosing the making of suspect transaction reports and permitting the international exchange of information concerning suspicious financial activity subject to appropriate confidentiality undertakings. These matters are addressed in the Bill.

As the Financial Action Task Force now includes participants from the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, and most have endorsed the recommendations, there is a growing body of information available internationally which will significantly assist in providing evidence of the true nature and extent of criminal activity in Australia and render both prosecution and confiscation more effective.

The Bill therefore amends the CTR Act to provide that I am entitled to have access to CTR information for the purpose of transmission to a foreign country to which the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987-the MA Act-applies. Where I am given access to CTR information for this purpose, and I am satisfied that the foreign country has given appropriate undertakings as to confidentiality and control of the information, I may communicate that information to the foreign country.

Proposed amendments to the MA Act in part 7 of the Bill permit regulations to be made, specifying a foreign country as a country to which the MA Act applies for the purpose of obtaining access to CTR information. Where such a country asks for such information I can direct the CTRA to give me access to that information for the purpose of complying with the request.

The Bill also amends the CTR Act to enable the Director of the CTRA to give access to CTR information to a wider range of domestic law enforcement agencies. These are the Independent Commission Against Corruption of New South Wales and the Criminal Justice Commission of Queensland. The ability to conduct financial investigations is central to the investigation of corruption, and the investigative functions of these bodies will be greatly assisted by access to CTR information.

The Bill contains a provision requiring the Director to provide me with an annual report on the operation of the CTRA. The availability of annual reports will be of particular assistance to Parliament when the operations of the CTR Act are reviewed in 1993 in accordance with the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

The Bill also contains several amendments to clarify the intention underlying the new Federal sentencing legislation, which was enacted in the Crimes Legislation Amendment Act (No. 2) 1989 and came into force on 17 July 1990. The amendments are required to clarify the circumstances in which non-parole periods and recognisance releases should be fixed. It is the intention of the legislation that, where the total federal sentence is less than 3 years and the court wishes the person to be released under supervision, the court can only make an order for the release of the person on recognisance. Where the aggregate sentence is greater than 3 years the intention of the legislation is that the courts be able to make either a recognisance release order or fix a non-parole period. Because there have been doubts expressed about the operation of the relevant sections, namely, sections 19ab, 19ac, 19ad and 19ae, these sections have been repealed and replaced. In addition, the opportunity has been taken to make a small number of minor technical amendments.

Several parts of the Bill amend provisions of the various Commonwealth Acts dealing with confiscation of assets. The Proceeds of Crime Act was enacted in 1987 and was a major new weapon for law enforcement in Australia. It is encouraging to note the increasing success of the new procedures introduced by the Act. Until 30 June 1990, recoveries and forfeitures under the Proceeds of Crime Act-and the related provisions of the Customs Act-have totalled nearly $7m. In addition, the net value of property restrained to meet future orders was nearly $47m as at 30 June 1990.

Since 1987 a number of decisions by courts exercising jurisdiction under the Act have shown that there is a need for minor modification of the Act. This Bill proposes those changes, and also proposes amendment of the corresponding provisions of the Customs Act and the Crimes (Superannuation Benefits) Act. The amendments are all of a minor policy nature and are discussed fully in the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated to honourable members.

The Bill will make amendments to the National Crime Authority Act 1984 to give the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) Government the same status as the State and Northern Territory governments and to allow it to participate in the activities of the Inter-Governmental Committee. This is appropriate now that the ACT has responsibility for its own criminal matters.

The participation and cooperation of the ACT in the activities of the National Crime Authority (NCA) is essential to the national focus and scope of the Authority's investigations. It is only the issuing of references by State and Territory governments that provides the NCA with the powers necessary to investigate offences across State/Territory boundaries. The NCA operates as a cooperative national law enforcement agency. The inclusion of the ACT in this process reflects the Territory's status within the Commonwealth.

The ACT is currently drafting its own underpinning legislation and the amendments to the Commonwealth legislation will not commence until the ACT legislation is passed. If, however, the amendments are not proclaimed after six months they will be automatically repealed. This is to ensure that important NCA operations in the ACT are not prejudiced by delays in the passage of the ACT law.

As a result of an initiative of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, the Bill contains amendments to the Crimes Act and Passports Act which are designed to render more effective the existing power of the Minister under the Passports Act 1938 to cancel or refuse to issue a passport to persons charged with, or convicted of, a serious narcotics offence or other prescribed offence against a Commonwealth or Territory law.

Section 7b of the Passports Act already prevents an authorised passport officer from issuing a passport to a person if the officer has reason to believe that the person is, by order of a court or under a condition of parole, recognisance, surety or bail bond, to remain in Australia or to refrain from obtaining an Australian passport. The Act also provides that a passport, whether in the possession of the person to whom it was issued or not, can be cancelled by the Minister.

The proposed amendments empower a court, when imposing bail or recognisance conditions or sentencing a person for such an offence, to order the person to remain in Australia, refrain from applying for an Australian passport or to surrender any Australian passport. The order may be varied or revoked as the court sees fit. A copy of any order made by the court must be given to the department administering the Passports Act and the registrar must retain any passport surrendered until the order ceases to have effect or the passport is cancelled or expires.

As the proposed scheme was the subject of a reference to the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, the Bill inserts a new section in the Crimes Act designed to complement any State law empowering courts to make orders in relation to passport surrender.

The only change to the Passports Act contained in this Bill is to amend section 7b to provide additional grounds for the refusal of a passport where the requirement to remain in Australia is a condition of release by licence or any similar instrument of early release granted under State or Territory law.

The totality of these relatively minor amendments is in my view a significant strengthening of our legislation to ensure that persons charged with serious offences cannot evade detection and prosecution nor reap the benefits of their illegal activities. I commend the Bill to the House and present the related explanatory memorandum.

DEBATE.TITLE: SERVICE AND EXECUTION OF PROCESS AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Duffy, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

In August last year I announced that the Government had decided to repeal and replace the Service and Execution of Process Act 1901, following consideration of the Law Reform Commission's report on service and execution of process.

One of the Law Reform Commission's recommendations mentioned in the announcement was an extension of the Act to proceedings before tribunals. At present the Act only applies to proceedings before courts. This extension would apply with respect to tribunals that resolve disputes and to tribunals that conduct inquiries.

As honourable members are aware, a number of important inquiries are being conducted in Australia at present. I refer particularly to the royal commissions in Victoria, Western Australia, South Australia and Tasmania.

This Bill amends the Service and Execution of Process Act to enable royal commissions and other investigative tribunals to serve subpoenas on persons interstate, and to provide for interstate enforcement of subpoenas to give evidence to investigative tribunals. The new provisions are based on the Law Reform Commission's recommendations. The Act already provides for interstate service and interstate enforcement of subpoenas issued by courts.

As well as enabling investigative tribunal subpoenas to be served interstate the Bill provides appropriate safeguards to protect the interests of persons served with an interstate subpoena. At present State or Territory royal commissions and other inquiries can effectively subpoena witnesses only within the State or Territory concerned. This can be a serious restriction on the effectiveness of the inquiry and can inhibit its capacity to uncover all relevant information.

The Government believes investigative tribunals, including the royal commissions I have mentioned, should be given the power now to summons witnesses from interstate. These tribunals must be able to conduct full and thorough inquiries so that the greatest possible public benefit can ensue.

The Government is bringing forward this reform as a separate Bill, rather than in the Bill to replace the Service and Execution of Process Act, so that it will be available for current inquiries. The chairman of one royal commission has informed the Government he considers that, without the powers being conferred by this Bill, the commission's work may be restricted in some important respects.

Because of the Government's heavy legislative program the replacement Bill will not be ready for introduction until the next sittings. As it is a substantial law reform Bill we would then wish there to be adequate time for examination of the Bill by honourable members, the legal profession and the public, before it is passed.

This Bill will insert a new part 3a into the Service and Execution of Process Act. That part will apply to investigative tribunals which, for the purposes of the part, will be persons appointed by a State Governor-such as royal commissions of inquiry-or under a State or Territory law, and bodies established under a State or Territory law, for the purposes of inquiring into and reporting on matters, where those persons or bodies have the power to take evidence on oath or affirmation.

A subpoena requiring evidence to be produced to such a tribunal will be able to be served out of the State or Territory of issue, by leave of that State or Territory's Supreme Court. Leave may only be granted where the court is satisfied that the evidence sought is relevant to the tribunal's functions and cannot reasonably be obtained from a person within the State or Territory. The Supreme Court will specify the date by which the subpoena must be served. A notice will be attached to the subpoena setting out the rights and obligations of the person to whom it is addressed.

Reasonable expenses of complying with the subpoena will have to be paid to the person subpoenaed. That obligation will be placed upon the State or Territory in which the tribunal is established. A person subpoenaed only to produce documents or things will be able to comply with the subpoena by delivering them to the secretary of the tribunal not less than 24 hours before the date for compliance.

Where a subpoena is addressed to a person in prison, the Supreme Court of the State or Territory in which the subpoena was issued will be able to order that the prisoner be taken interstate to give evidence. The State or Territory in which that order was made will be required to pay the expenses reasonably incurred in connection with compliance with the order.

I appreciate that there is a question whether the Commonwealth has power to legislate to provide for the service and execution of process of State tribunals. The Government has been advised that it has power to do so under section 51(xxiv) of the Constitution, which confers power with respect to `the service and execution throughout the Commonwealth of the civil and criminal process and the judgments of the courts of the States.'
The Bill is expected to have no impact on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue. I commend the Bill to the House and table the explanatory memorandum.

DEBATE.TITLE: GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE PARK AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mrs Kelly, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: THE ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Mrs KELLY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
Both Labor and coalition governments have in the past supported the protection and wise use of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, and I hope that this bipartisan support will continue.

It has been 16 years since the passage of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act and the creation of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. Over that time practical experience gained from managing the marine park has highlighted areas where protection of the reef could be improved.

The Government has noted with concern the effects of spillage of oil and other toxic substances on the marine environment around the world and is of the view that such risks to the Great Barrier Reef should be minimised as much as possible. The effects of an incident such as that of the Exxon Valdez would be quite disastrous to the Great Barrier Reef environment, and even smaller spills of toxic material would be very damaging.

The purpose of this Bill is to improve the protection of the Great Barrier Reef against possible spillages of oil and other toxic substances by introducing compulsory pilotage through the northern inner shipping routes of the reef. These routes offer relatively calm waters, but are shallow and intricate in places. Approximately 10 per cent of the 2,000 large ships or ships carrying potentially hazardous cargo using the passage every year are not adhering to the current voluntary system of pilotage. Extensive diplomatic representations have not brought a higher level of compliance with the voluntary scheme. The Government acknowledges the 90 per cent of ships which do adhere to the present system of voluntary pilotage. The responsibility of their masters and owners is appreciated.

The current voluntary pilotage system covers ships of 100 metres in length and over, as well as ships carrying potentially hazardous cargo. A lower limit of 70 metres has been set in the new system because of the number of groundings of ships in the 70 metre to 100 metre range occurring in recent years. There has been at least one per year.

Australia is committed to the uniform application and development of international law and international cooperation, rather than unilateral action, in protecting our marine environment. Hence we sought recognition by the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) for the special status of the Great Barrier Reef and endorsement of the compulsory pilotage system.

Australia was successful in having the IMO pass two important resolutions in November 1990. The first was to identify the Great Barrier Reef region as a `particularly sensitive area'-the first such listed area in the world. The second was its recommendation that all governments recognise the need for effective protection of the Great Barrier Reef region and inform ships flying their flag to act in accordance with Australia's system of pilotage.

This is the first time that the international community has endorsed such a system. It marks a new development in international law, recognising the dynamic balance which exists between protection of the marine environment and freedom of navigation. The proposed amendments to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act will give effect to these IMO resolutions.

Vessels meeting criteria recognised in the IMO resolutions will be required to use the services of a person holding a Queensland and Torres Strait pilot's licence while navigating the inner route or Hydrographers Passage.

At present pilots hold licences as coastal pilots issued by the Marine Board of Queensland. These licences will be recognised in the regulations. The regulations will also enable additional licences to be introduced. It is intended that there be extensive consultation with interested parties and organisations before any other forms of licensing are introduced.

Three offences have been created to enforce the compulsory pilotage system. In the first, the master and owner of any vessel over 70 metres and any loaded oil tanker, chemical carrier or liquefied gas carrier, irrespective of size, will be liable to prosecution if that vessel navigates without the assistance of a pilot in the areas between the northern boundary of the marine park and latitude 16 degrees 40 minutes south, and also in Hydrographers Passage, which is just off Mackay. The maximum penalty imposed following conviction would be $50,000.

The other two offences are linked to the subsequent entry into an Australian port of a vessel which has navigated in the designated areas without a pilot. In the first of these two, both the owner and the master will be liable to prosecution if the ship enters an Australian port under the command of the master who navigated in the compulsory pilotage area without a pilot. In the second, if a ship navigates in the compulsory pilotage area without a pilot and later enters an Australian port under the command of a different master, only the owner will be liable. Again, the maximum penalty imposed would be $50,000. These port entry related offences have been included to take advantage of the clear authority which Australia has under international law to control the entry of vessels into its ports.

The Government intends that inspectors appointed with respect to compulsory pilotage will normally be officers of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. AMSA officers are more likely than Great Barrier Reef Marine Park officers to be in a position to exercise the power to seek evidence concerning pilotage as they frequently board vessels to carry out inspections under the Navigation Act 1912.

The reason the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act has been chosen to implement the compulsory pilotage system is to indicate Australia's commitment to greater protection for the Great Barrier Reef environment. It clearly demonstrates to the international community that the measures are aimed at reducing navigational hazards in this particularly sensitive area, for its enhanced protection.

After these measures are introduced and enforced, the rate of compliance, already 90 per cent under the voluntary pilotage scheme, is expected to be total. A particularly vulnerable part of the reef will thus be more effectively protected from the possibility of an environmental disaster caused by a shipping mishap.

In deciding on this course of action, the Government considered other options, including the suggestion by some conservation groups that tankers should be prohibited from the region. This was rejected as impractical for a number of reasons:

1. Much of the tanker traffic operating inside the reef is servicing the population centres of far north Queensland. Without access to such shipping these communities and the industries on which they are dependent, such as tourism, agriculture and mining, would not be able to satisfy their energy and other needs.

2. The waters of alternative routes in the Coral Sea are less sheltered and less well served with navigation aids. Ships transiting via these routes therefore constitute an equal or greater risk to the environment than those inside the reef.

3. Ships navigating in the inner route of the Great Barrier Reef are exercising the right of innocent passage under international law. It would not be open to Australia to completely restrict this right.

In conclusion, this Bill represents the Government's resolve to improve the protection of one of the world's greatest natural assets, the Great Barrier Reef. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill, and I commend this Bill to the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Baldwin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BALDWIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Australian National University Bill 1991 provides for the amalgamation of the Australian National University and the Canberra Institute of the Arts from 1 January 1992. In July 1989 the Australian National University (ANU) and the Canberra Institute of the Arts finalised an affiliation agreement with a view to amalgamating by 1 January 1991. In July 1990 the university and the Institute of the Arts agreed to amalgamate.

Legislation to give effect to this amalgamation was to be introduced into Parliament last year but was deferred because of the possibility that the report of the committee to review the Institute of Advanced Studies of the Australian National University-the Stephen report-would have legislative implications. This has proved not to be the case.

Honourable members will be aware that I made a statement earlier this year on arrangements for higher education in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) on the basis of advice contained within the Stephen report and the advice from Professor Chubb. In that statement I endorsed new administrative arrangements which will encourage the Australian National University and the University of Canberra to coordinate their efforts and cooperate more closely in order to provide the best possible educational opportunities for the region. I also endorsed new funding arrangements for the Institute of Advanced Studies of the Australian National University which will enhance the institute's role as a national resource and result in an appropriate performance evaluation and peer review process to guarantee the best use of research funds.

Honourable members could not have failed to notice the reports in the media about these decisions. There has been persistent misrepresentation of the Government's intentions towards the Institute of Advanced Studies. On Friday 10 May, I met with the ANU council to discuss points of difference in relation to the Government's decisions.

This provided me with an opportunity to clarify a number of key points with council members. I stressed that key issues such as the performance criteria to be applied every five years and the composition of the review panels evaluating each school and centre within the Institute would be matters on which the Administrative Review Council (ARC) would need to consult, and seek agreement with, the ANU.

However, the Government continues to believe that it is legitimate and appropriate for it to be able to receive expert advice from the ARC, the only body with broad-based knowledge of research activity throughout the higher education system, except the National Health and Medical Research Council for medical research, as to the overall distribution of research funds between the Institute of Advanced Studies and the rest of the higher education research system. In arriving at such advice, the ARC would draw on the reviews of each component of the institute and would notionally apportion a level of funding to each. It is not the Government's intention, however, to require that the ANU's internal resource allocation decisions would correspond to its own notional apportionment.

There is no implication in any of this that the institute's funding should be cut-in fact, the new review arrangements could mean more funds. Like Stephen, I acknowledge the high quality of much of the institute's research and see value in retaining a concentration of research resources and personnel. However, funding at the level provided to the institute must be a demonstrably effective use of scarce research funds and the Government, quite properly, will demand advice on the `opportunity cost' involved in funding the institute at a given level compared with other research activities in the higher education research system.

I reiterate, however, that the present Bill is entirely separate from these new arrangements for higher education in the ACT. Its purpose is to put into effect a longstanding agreement to amalgamate between the Australian National University and the Canberra Institute of the Arts. The Bill abolishes the Institute of the Arts as a separate institution and adds to the functions of the university the requirement that it provide facilities for courses at higher education and other levels in the visual and performing arts and, in doing so, promotes the highest standards in those fields. The Bill also provides for the students and staff of the Institute of the Arts to be transferred to the university on terms and conditions no less favourable than they enjoy at present.

The amalgamation can be expected to enhance the national and international roles of the university through the addition of the visual and performing arts to its range of disciplines while at the same time allowing the Institute of the Arts to become a member of the unified national system. With its small student load, the Institute of the Arts would be unable to enter the unified national system of higher education in its own right.

The amalgamation will permit students from both institutions to benefit from a wider range of course options. The development of higher degree courses at the Institute of the Arts will benefit from the university's greater experience in graduate education. In addition, the consolidation of adjacent campuses under one administration will lead to cost efficiencies and the rationalisation of shared services and amenities. The local community can expect to enjoy greater benefits from an expansion of university extension programs with the addition of more musical, art and gallery activities.

The Bill also provides for a change in the qualifications and method of appointment of members of council from the ACT. This change will exclude members of the Legislative Assembly of the Australian Capital Territory to ensure that members appointed from the ACT will be drawn from the wider community with either expertise or interest in the activities of the institution-for example, from the professions, industry, the trade union movement or community organisations. The appointment procedures will be streamlined in that the Chief Minister will be able to appoint the ACT members directly rather than making nominations to the Governor-General through the Commonwealth Minister. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991[COGNATE BILL:INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1991]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate resumes on this Bill, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill and the Industrial Relations Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the luncheon adjournment, I was telling the House that it is not only the trade union movement in the area of industrial relations which has hard won gains. The hardest won gain in the industrial relations debate over the last 10 years has been to establish-through the decisions of various courts in the Mudginberri case, the pilots dispute, the Dollar Sweets case, the meatworkers case, the gasfitters and plumbers case and, indeed, a number of other cases-something which would have been regarded as undreamt of, unheard of and an absolute industrial relations heresy in this country as recently as five or 10 years ago, and that is that trade unions, if they break the law, can like the rest of us be made accountable before the ordinary courts of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I said before lunch that the Opposition was uncompromisingly opposed to any legislative change that would alter that situation. It is a hard won gain to be able to say at long last in this country that in this area there is equality before the law.

It always amazed me that the Hancock Committee of Review of Industrial Relations Law and Systems could say, as it did in 1985, that we cannot make unions subject to the ordinary laws of this country because they are strong enough to disobey them. In substance that is what the Hancock Committee said on this issue.

I remember debating this subject with Professor Keith Hancock, a person whom I respect, at Flinders University in 1985 when I was Deputy Leader of the Opposition. He repeated that assertion. He believed that it was part of the industrial relations folklore of this country and something which could never be compromised. I disagreed with him then, and the course of events over the last five or six years has validated the position I then took.

Our concern is that the Government is conjuring up a deal with the Australian Democrats. Senator McLean is being well looked after. He has been to the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU); he has talked to the leaders of the movement; he is going to Geneva; and he is going to be very well looked after. Fair enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —A free trip to Geneva?

—I am not saying that the Government has any ulterior motive in doing that, but I wonder whether the precedent being established in relation to the visit to the International Labour Organisation (ILO)-that is, the Government's pattern of matching the Minister with the shadow Minister-is going to be repeated. On that three-month stint to New York, are we going to have an Australian Democrat, a member of the Opposition and a member of the Government comprising the Australian delegation to the United Nations in New York? I can be forgiven for believing that Senator McLean's invitation to the ILO is part of the pay-off for support for the Government's proposal to set up a labour court.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McLean's views on industrial relations are to the left of a number of people in the Australian Labor Party. I grant the Labor Party that. He has indicated publicly on many occasions that he supports very strongly the centralised model with the Australian Industrial Relations Commission sitting at the pinnacle. In that sense, he is different from the Labor Party. I am not sure whether the Labor Party any longer supports a centralised model with the Industrial Relations Commission sitting at the pinnacle. As a result of the rejection of the Commission's decision in the national wage case, those of us who follow the industrial relations debate closely are genuinely puzzled as to whether or not the Government any longer supports that model.

I put it to the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis) and to the honourable member for Eden Monaro (Mr Snow), who follow these matters very closely and have some understanding of the industrial relations debate, that in this country there are really only two alternatives. We can either have an industrial relations system where the Commission is genuinely the umpire and the referee, on the understanding that the players do what the referee says; or, alternatively, we get rid of that centralised model and allow outright enterprise bargaining.

The Government and the ACTU rejected the wage case decision a few weeks ago. I can only believe that at that time the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was so disoriented by the problems he was having with former Ambassador Brian Burke that he took his eye off the game and was swept along by other people who wanted to join the ACTU in rejecting the decision. I cannot believe that the present Prime Minister, given his history with industrial relations, does not still believe in his heart that we ought to have the pure centralised model with the Industrial Relations Commission sitting at the pinnacle.

As honourable members in the House know, I have long wanted to change that model, but I am prepared to acknowledge that in a debate the best argument for the alternative to my policy is to argue the role of the Commission. As far as I am concerned, that made the decision of the Government to oppose the Commission's decision absolutely mind-boggling. To use the sporting parlance, it was like kicking an own goal in soccer. It is like Queensland going into the State of Origin without Wally Lewis. It is, from the Government's point of view, trying to run this industrial relations debate without arguing the role of the Commission. But it is not for me to advise the Government on tactics for that debate.

Going back to the labour court, we are concerned that the Government is in the process of buying off Democrat support for the labour court proposal. I remind the House-and, through it, supporters of the Australian Democrats-that in 1985, when the Australian Democrats were a different organisation, they opposed the Government's attempts to abolish sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act. That attempt by the Government effectively to abolish it by shifting it out of the Trade Practices Act was defeated.

I am concerned, with the passage of time and the change of attitude inside the Australian Democrats, that we are fast approaching a situation where the Government will present a Bill to the Parliament, in effect, to revive the labour court proposal of 1987. That labour court proposal is to shift to a new labour court, which would not be a proper court, in the sense that it would not be free of the mandatory resort to the Industrial Relations Commission before the remedies administered by that court could be made available to parties.

A labour court of the Government's 1987 model would not be able to enforce the remedies available under section 45d without first saying to the parties, `You go off to the Industrial Relations Commission. You try to sort out your argument. Then if you can't do it-and only then-you come back to us and we'll consider applying section 45d'.

If that happens, section 45d will be utterly and completely destroyed, because the real value of section 45d, as I said earlier, is that individual employers can go along and say, `Look, we are the subject of a secondary boycott. It is sending our business broke and unless we get immediate injunctive relief we are going to suffer the consequences of that secondary boycott'.

I say to the House, and to the Minister, that if that is not what the Government has in mind, why else would it still be thinking of a labour court proposal? Some people have said to me that what we really need to do is to put all of the industrial remedies into a special court. I am a very suspicious man and I always become very suspicious of people who want special courts. When there are special courts, there are special deals and special arrangements. They are different from the mainstream. If we believe very strongly, as I and the members of the Liberal and National parties do, that one of the milestones in the industrial relations achievement of the last 10 years has been to establish the principle that people are equal before the law and are fully accountable to the ordinary laws of this country, I suspect that what the Government has in mind will be a very serious step back from that.

I hope that all of the employer organisations in Australia understand the implications of what a labour court proposal would mean for the hard won gains of equality before the law. I know that most of those organisations do, but I am concerned that some of them may not. I would say to those organisations that it is simply not possible to have a labour court of the type this Government would undoubtedly have in mind and, with a straight face, to seriously say that we are going to have that but we are not going to touch the effective section 45d and common law remedies that are currently available.

The interesting thing about the application of the common law and section 45d to union conduct when it is in breach of the law is that, like the rest of us, trade union officials take notice of ordinary courts. When we are told by an ordinary court to do something, we normally do it, because we know that in a law abiding community there are certain consequences. The same thing applies to union officials. I have never believed, as some have alleged, that all union officials are in some way less respectful towards the ordinary laws of this country. Most of them have as much commitment to the rules of law as I have. They take notice of ordinary courts: that is why they do not like being subject to ordinary courts, and that is why the supporters of the traditional approach to industrial relations in Australia have always wanted special arrangements. They are, in a sense, frightened of themselves when it comes to ordinary courts, because they have to take notice of them.

It was an achievement getting that principle established over the last 10 years. I acknowledge the generous and fulsome contribution-nobody made a greater contribution-of the Prime Minister to establishing the principle of accountability of unions to the ordinary courts of this country.

Let it be remembered in this debate that it was the Prime Minister who encouraged the airlines of this country to sue the Australian Federation of Airline Pilots. He encouraged them to sue the pilots because he said that they had a case. At no stage did he argue that the Australian Federation of Airline Pilots, a trade union, should not be made accountable to the ordinary courts of Australia. I congratulate the Prime Minister for doing that, and I thank him, because he has made a magnificent contribution to establishing that very important principle. I say to the Prime Minister, `Don't upset that principle; don't be seduced by Martin Ferguson, Senator Cook or anybody else into embracing the labour court proposal'.

In a political sense I suppose I should hope that the Government does embrace the labour court proposal. Such has been the change of mood on industrial relations around Australia over the last year or so that I believe the coalition could fill every hall in every provincial city of Australia in leading protests against the establishment of a labour court which would take away that hard-won gain of having the union movement-like everybody else, not in any discriminatory way-subject to the ordinary laws of Australia.

In talking about the alternative industrial relations policy of the coalition, I have repeatedly said that there are four fundamental changes that we wish to make. Firstly, we want to give to individual employers and their employees the right, if they choose-subject to the observance of a minimum wage and subject to the observance of health and public safety laws-the right to make bargains at an enterprise level without the intervention of unions, employer organisations or industrial tribunals. We are not saying that everybody must do that. We are saying that they may do that if they so wish. As everyone in this Parliament knows, we cannot do that under the present law. If we want to do our own deal we can only do it through a union or through an industrial relations tribunal. We believe that that requirement is burdensome, unnecessary and anti-productivity in many cases. If people so wish they should have the right to do their own deal.

The second fundamental principle is that we are totally opposed to the closed shop and compulsory unionism. We intend to entrench the principle of voluntary unionism. The level of private sector membership of unions in Australia is now about 31 per cent. The overall percentage of 42 per cent is boosted by the fact that some 68 per cent of people in the public sector belong to unions, due almost entirely to the de facto compulsory unionism that exists in the public sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are plenty not in unions.

—I know that there are plenty not in unions. The honourable member for Eden-Monaro correctly interjects that there are plenty not in unions. Of course, there are plenty not in unions. My argument very simply is that it should be purely and simply a matter of choice. We will never place a penalty on people who want to join a union. We will maintain the tax deductibility of bona fide union dues. There will be no attempt by us to put a penalty on people who belong to unions, but we will prevent people being forced to join unions. In this day and age that is an utterly unexceptionable principle.

SPEECH.PARA: The third pillar of our industrial relations policy is to allow the emergence, once again if they are desired, of enterprise unions. We are not saying that we have to have enterprise unions. We are not saying that we cannot have craft unions or industry unions. We are saying that if we want to have an enterprise union we should have the freedom to do so. That is why we oppose the foolish change the Government made to the Act only a few months ago to introduce a minimum membership level of 10,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Super unions.

—That is just crazy. I think it is a super mistake, rather than being a super union. I cannot think of anything more illogical, seriously-I say this to honourable members opposite-than to be running around the country saying, as the Government is, `We believe in enterprise bargaining and we believe in exalting the enterprise. The enterprise, right or wrong, is going to be the theme of the 1990s. The enterprise is beautiful', when in the next breath it says, `Hang on, we are going to make it impossible to belong to a union, to have a union, unless you have 10,000 members'. It is a contradiction; the two things are going in the opposite directions.

SPEECH.PARA: The final principle that is a pillar, a cornerstone, one of the irreducible minima of our policy, is equality before the law. That brings me back to the substance of our objection to this Bill. We believe that everybody should be subject to the ordinary laws of this country, administered by the ordinary courts. We will have no truck with toy courts and we will not compromise on our opposition to the re-establishment of the labour court idea.

I say to the Government: if it wants to resurrect the labour court proposal it should go ahead and do so. It will cost it very dearly in political terms. It will be a retrograde step in terms of ordinary principles of industrial relations justice and, if it is successful, it will overturn for a temporary period what many Australians regard as a hard won gain-that is, the simple proposition that in a nation that has always prided itself on its egalitarian principles it is surely not unreasonable to say that everybody should be equal before the law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis Mr A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is something of a pleasure to listen to the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard); he is a genuine craftsman. It is a real pity that, craftsman as he is, he gets things wrong as often as he does. He has quoted the aberrations in the industrial relations system as the norm, as if they were to be followed. It would appear that he has reverted to a view that I thought he had gone beyond some years ago-that the answer to industrial relations problems is the threat, the penalty, the sanctions mechanisms, and that is how we should regulate disputes between people in industrial relations and how we should regulate disputes on award conditions, rates of pay and the like. All of this is then wrapped in and camouflaged by the rhetoric of free choice, which is a phrase I will come back to. It is one of the great misleading features of the Opposition's position on industrial relations.

SPEECH.PARA: It is almost one year ago to the day that I made my maiden speech in this place. In the course of that speech I said:
One of the key areas which will be pivotal in ensuring a strong and competitive Australia is industrial relations.
The events of the last 12 months, and particularly the last six months, have demonstrated just how true that is. I went on to say:

It is sad to note that at a time when enormous strides have been taken in industrial relations, with changes occurring in workplace practices, with award restructuring and with second-tier negotiations of recent years, the conservative parties in Australian politics have opted for a course of confrontation, for a return to the simplistic and basic right wing fundamentalist views characterised by groups such as the H.R. Nicholls Society.

The performance of the honourable member for Bennelong and the sorts of things that we have heard said by the Opposition in recent months on industrial relations re-enforced that view I expressed 12 months ago.

In the last decade there has been an enormous improvement in industrial relations in this country which is one of the major achievements of the Hawke Labor Government. There can be no denying that the in the last decade we have replaced the entrenched confrontation which so characterised the 1960s and 1970s with negotiation and consensus. The Government has facilitated union amalgamations. I wish I had the time to talk more about that because clearly there are some major differences between the Government and the Opposition on this point. Again, I believe the Government is correct. The Opposition's view is myopic.

We have provided stability throughout industrial relations and the spin-offs that provides for our economy through the operation of the accord. Probably the best barometer of that, and the one which throughout the 1960s and 1970s would have been used most often as a criticism of the way in which industrial relations operated, was the number of strikes-the number of days lost to strikes per thousand employees. If we look at those figures throughout the 1970s and the 1980s we have confirmed the view that industrial action has subsided dramatically throughout the 1980s. At the end of the 1970s we were witnessing highs of 780 working days lost per 1,000 employees. That was not just in one year; 780, 680 and 780 working days were lost in successive years at the end of the 1970s and the early 1980s. In 1989 that figure was down to 190, less than a quarter of the peak. Now it is operating slightly above that; the latest figures are 220 working days lost per 1,000 employees.

The facts are that industrial relations in the last 10 years has seen a return to sensible negotiation and constructive development of our economy trying to set right the problems we have in our factories and our workplaces, but doing it in a way which is not only economically sensible but socially just.

One of the other spin-offs from the accord has been a reduction in unit labour costs to a level which is now lower in real terms than it has been for a decade. I noticed the other day in Question Time that members of the Opposition interjected on that point. One of the things that tend to be forgotten when that figure is referred to is the benefit that this Government has provided, as a result of the accord, in the social wage-things such as the increases in the family allowance, the introduction of the family allowance supplement, Austudy, child-care fee relief and Medicare. These benefits have all improved in a dramatic way the social wage of Australian wage and salary earners.

We are talking about significant sums of money for ordinary working Australians. The family allowance supplement provides a family with two children under 13 years of age up to $106 a fortnight tax free. Families can receive up to $85 a week for child-care fee relief. These substantial tax free payments in the hand are a direct result of the accord which the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions have negotiated. The Opposition has failed to acknowledge them as a major step forward in industrial relations and an improvement in the quality of life of many Australians. These achievements and many others are now being threatened by the sorts of policies that the Liberal-National coalition and the more extreme elements within employer groups have been promulgating over recent months.

I want to refer to the fundamental question of hours of work. During the adjournment debate on 9 May I referred to a Courier-Mail article which reported the Queensland Confederation of Industry (QCI) as saying that it believed that Queensland industries would benefit from a return to a 48-hour working week. As I mentioned the other night, the 48-hour working week was the standard in 1904 when the industrial relations system was established. In April of this year the Queensland Confederation of Industry suggested that we would all benefit from working a standard rate of 48 hours a week.

I was somewhat flattered on 9 May when a member of the Opposition front bench was motivated, following my adjournment speech, to come into the House and respond to my comments. I should say that on reflection I concede that it was only the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) and not truly a cause for any great excitement.

The Opposition has made clear its position on the question of hours. On a number of occasions the honourable member for Bennelong has pointed out his support for a 40-hour week. His view is opposed not only by this Government and the trade union movement but also by employers. On 19 February, a day or possibly two days after a press release was issued by the honourable member for Bennelong, the Australian Financial Review included an article which said:
Both the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Business Council of Australia have rejected the proposition made by the Opposition's spokesman on industrial relations, Mr Howard.
This was concerning the 40-hour week.

TALK.START.PARA: —It shows that we are even-handed.

—It does, indeed. It also shows that the Business Council of Australia and the Confederation of Australian Industry, whose support we can normally rely on in matters of this kind, were not willing to give endorsement to what they regarded as a rather foolish policy which I am surprised the honourable member still sticks to. I would have thought that by now he would have resiled from that position.

SPEECH.PARA: The statement of the honourable member for Bennelong was reported in other newspapers. Clearly, other interviews were given. Those statements go to the heart of what the honourable member for Bennelong has said today about industry agreements.

I have no problem, as a member of the Australian Labor Party and as a former trade union official, with enterprise agreements negotiated between unions and employers, preferably within the national guidelines and approved by a commission. I was somewhat surprised and disappointed that-and, admittedly, his remarks had been paraphrased-the honourable member for Bennelong indicated that there were only two courses that could be followed in determining wage--

TALK.START.PARA: —Three.

—There are three courses-I must have missed one. I understood the honourable member to say that there were only two. The question of how many solutions and mechanisms there are to resolve industrial matters is a bit broader than that. A little bit of lateral thinking would have helped overcome the hurdle of only two or three options.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, I have no problems with enterprise agreements negotiated fairly between unions and employers within known guidelines and preferably approved by a commission. There should be an understanding across the country within the jurisdiction, be it State or Federal, of the ground rules and an understanding of the base conditions which apply.

However, that is not the sort of industrial agreement or enterprise agreement which the Opposition and the major employer organisations are proposing. The hidden agenda behind what is being proposed by the Opposition is far more sinister. In a Sunday Telegraph article of 24 February, the honourable member for Bennelong is reported as having said:
However, under a Coalition government much of the labor market would move to negotiations at an enterprise level instead of being tied to the centralised system.
That is fine, as far as that goes. The article went on to say:
For example, if you wanted to work a 50-hour week it would be a matter for negotiation.

That reminds me a little bit of the Opposition's health policy under which it is going to replace Medicare and replace it with vouchers. The Opposition health spokesman has told us that some people will be worse off but only by choice. One will choose to be worse off. We have a nation of masochists waiting to be inflicted with this pain. The honourable member for Bennelong says that if people wish to negotiate a 50-hour week as their standard hourly basis, they can do that as a matter of choice. The article went on to state:
`Until we have a system where working hours can be negotiated at an enterprise level the Government should approach the Industrial Relations Commission to bring back a general 40-hour working week.

So there we have the clear scenario that we should now move to increased working hours for Australians through the award system, that we should move to make it 40 hours but as soon as we can free up the award system to let enterprise agreements be established, we want to see it go above 40 hours. In April the QCI told us that it wants to see it go to 48 hours.

On 9 May I put the question to members of the Opposition who were in the chamber, `What is your policy? What do you see as the standard hours of work which should apply for ordinary Australians?'. It is a question that they should address before the next election. The people of Australia will want to know whether under the Opposition's stewardship they will be facing 40 hours, 48 hours or, as the honourable member for Bennelong has suggested, 50 hours.

If the honourable member and his supporters are committed to enterprise agreements, the approach needs to be even-handed. The process of enterprise agreements means that some people might in fact do a little bit better. The only enterprise agreements that I have seen the Opposition and employer organisations herald are those that seek to reduce conditions below base award rates. That is the practice overseas-it is the practice in New Zealand, the United States of America and Britain.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Powers?
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor is continually interjecting. He is going to speak in this debate. I would suggest that he remain silent until he gets the call.
—It is also the practice here in Australia. I want to quote from an article in the Courier-Mail of January of this year. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Queensland's private schools were yesterday granted permission to oppose an award which would give teachers at a Brisbane school up to $6,000 a year more than their State-award colleagues.

That is not surprising-one would expect the employers to oppose an award claim that would provide teachers in one school with $6,000 more than their colleagues elsewhere. But that is not the way it was. The $6,000 increase was in fact a negotiated enterprise agreement. The article continued:
The Queensland Confederation of Industry is leading the campaign against the John Paul College agreement.
It then says-and this the absolute height of hypocrisy:
The QCI is the State's leading employer group and one of the strongest supporters of enterprise bargaining.

The teachers' union in Queensland which covers those people negotiated an enterprise agreement without industrial action that resulted in a $6,000 a year pay increase. The first thing the champions of enterprise agreement wanted to do was to get down to the Commission and stop it becoming law.

Honourable members opposite, the Queensland Confederation of Industry, the Australian Confederation of Industry and the other employer groups have consistently demonstrated their support for enterprise agreements that reduce conditions. Whenever there has been an enterprise agreement that seeks to dramatically improve conditions, negotiated freely between the union and the employer, they are off to the Commission-a commission which they say we should not have; a commission which should not interfere in these matters-in a effort to stop those agreements being registered. That is in fact what has been occurring in Queensland in the last month with the Queensland Confederation of Industry. It is mockery for the honourable member for Bennelong to stand here and claim otherwise.

As time is short in the debate today, I simply wish to round off by reminding the Opposition and the people of Australia that fair-minded Australians will again reject the sort of provocative policies that would return Australian industrial relations to the mindless confron-tation of the 1960s and the 1970s.

The Hawke Government will continue to work with unions and employers to collectively improve our work practices, in what has been and will continue to be a socially and economically responsible manner. I commend the Bill to the Parliament.

That is his worry and that is the problem with the whole industrial relations system in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member has just told us how everything is going to be worked out. I have no time for employer bureaucrats either, because I think both sets of bureaucrats are in the one club. They all sit there scratching one another's backs. They are never out of work when there is a strike. In fact, I believe they claim overtime. I can remember saying to the members of my hotel staff-about 40 of them at the time-`Look, I am fed up with my wife having to spend all morning working out your wages at all the various rates that now apply in a highly complex award. Those opposite do not want that. Go away and talk; be closed down for a week; have some negotiations'-the employer is broke at the end of the week-`and then come back and we'll see what we can do for you'. That is what those opposite want because that is fundamental to their negotiating position.

That is not what the Opposition wants. We believe that both sides should be able to sit down and talk about it and get a result, without closing down the business. Who are the losers when a business is shut down? The workers themselves do not do too well. When they get their pay rise at the end of it and the wages they have lost are deducted, it takes them about eight years to recover lost wages after a prolonged strike. I can give the House examples of exactly that happening in the Pilbara. It took 10 years for one group of workers to recover what they lost in pay while they struck for what was eventually $10 a week, led on by some trade union bureaucrat. Those workers did not like it very much; I can tell honourable members this because the workers talked to me. What I am saying is that under what we propose people can be paid in terms of their productivity.

This morning we had the Treasurer (Mr Keating) telling us about how he has achieved a drop in inflation. He has certainly done that, as 850,000 unemployed people will attest. The simple fact is that he has tried every so-called economic instrument to bludgeon the economy into this situation, and he has done it at a huge price.

Under the productivity proposals of the Opposition, we can have nil inflation simply by maintaining productivity relative to wage increases. The point I make to the House is that we can do that, and the first beneficiaries are the worker's wife and family because when they go down to the shops the prices are still the same. That is how we can contain inflation and keep jobs. Unless the Government understands that, it will never get this country on its feet. Its instrument has put 850,000 people out of work, and that is not very bright.

I shall finish now because I presume the reason the Opposition Whip, the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson), has come along is to lean on me a little. I have just been complaining about that! The whole point about it is that people can have individual wage agreements and get paid relative to what they do. The more the merrier, as far as I am concerned. I hope our policies will double wages; they certainly do pretty well for the blokes at Lincoln Electric. A survey in Canada has shown that companies that pay productivity bonuses make 12 per cent more profit. It is a good idea. Government members should embrace it, not try to bully people and just keep their jobs because they need them. That is the major problem now.

There are many other things I would like to have said. I get quite wrapped up in this. For the information of the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis), I too made my maiden speech in this place on industrial relations.

The Opposition is really about getting rid of union power, which was hard won, which is important and has been important in the history of our country and of the world. I called on Father John Morrison, the local relieving priest, when he happened to be at Braidwood one day, not long before his retirement. He asked me about my support of unions. He said, `Young man'-I was over 50 then-`the trade unions have made this country'. He is so right. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This has been an invigorating debate this evening, has it not? I am delighted to enter the fray. It is a great shame, though, that the Government saw fit, or at least claims that it is necessary, to gag debate on such an important issue, and one that so many on both sides of the House seem to have the desire to address. I will confine my remarks to the first of the Bills, the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill, and I refer honourable members to the second reading speech of the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) wherein he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is particularly important that there is flexibility to appoint tribunal members with appropriate knowledge and experience, including an appreciation of current industrial relations issues and government administration.

That is a mouthful, is it not? Goodness gracious! The Minister has said that it is the system itself which is all important. It is the system, not the results, not the outcomes that count in this debate about industrial relations. We must at all costs maintain our highly structured, rigid, inflexible, dogmatic industrial relations system and the club that drives it. The Minister continued:

The existing seven year disqualification period has created difficulties in finding replacement members of the Tribunal with the necessary skills and experience to enable them to operate effectively. Members of the Tribunal are required to have regard to the wage fixing principles of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and, therefore, need to be cognisant of the principles of contemporary wage fixing arrangements. Accordingly, a more flexible provision is required. An amendment is therefore proposed to the Act to reduce the disqualification period from seven years to one year . . .

What a lot of rot! This Bill admits that this totally inflexible, rigid, centralised system, which it is so imperative that we maintain, is now faced with the real problem in finding competent people who are entrenched within the system to act on the tribunal. Well, that is sad, but so what?

The problem we have is that this Bill provides that the Commission is an example of jobs for the boys. If someone is not within the system, he cannot play the game. No system, no game; nothing happens. The Government must continually fix up its own industrial relations legislation in order to make the system work because the system is so highly legally based.

I tell honourable members and you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that industrial relations labour law in Australia today is in a crisis. No-one from either side of the House in this debate has any confidence that this Government, the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) or the Industrial Relations Commission have any idea in what direction the system is going. The Government and the ACTU, in accord mark 6, stitched up the latest deal which made a decision on working conditions for every man and woman in every enterprise and at every location across this vast nation. We might as well be in communist Russia, might we not?

What happened was that two sides of the triumvirate, the Government and the ACTU, made their agreement, stitched up a deal and then went to the Commission. For once the Commission did not play; for once it stood up to the accord partners and said, `No, boys. This is not in the national interest. We are going to play the game a different way'. So what happened? The Government and the ACTU took the ball and the bat and went home. They said, `We will start all over again'.
Let us examine what some people had to say about that particular issue. I refer honourable members to the Age of 15 May 1991 where Mr Kelty is quoted as saying:
Power is not something you can achieve by the unilateral assertion of it.

Of course it is not. Where has the trade union developed its power from? It developed its base of power in the field. It has consolidated that power in its stitched up deals with its mates in this Federal Government; that is the basis of the accord deals. But now the accord deals are not working because the Commission will not play. So the system is falling down and the system does not work. That always happens to complex systems. That is what happens when one creates cartels-they work for a while but they are never totally successful and, at the end of the day, cartels always fail. That is what we have in industrial relations in Australia-a cartel between the bureaucracy of the labour movement, the bureaucracy of the Government, the bureaucracy of enterprise management associations, and the bureaucracy of the Industrial Relations Commission. Mr Kelty went on to say:
I think there are a lot of people out there who have not got the benefits of award restructuring and as a consequence have been exploited.

People have been exploited because he believes that the last deal stitched up by the ACTU and the Government has not been totally delivered in the field. I remind honourable members that less than 40 per cent of the work force in this country now belong to trade unions. But the trade unions still represent them. It is absolutely necessary, is it not?

We do not have compulsory union membership, unless one happens to be in the construction industry or the meat industry or one happens to work for the Commonwealth Government or a State Government. Exploited-goodness gracious! Here we are in the middle of the greatest recession for 60 years and we are talking about exploiting workers by not granting dramatic pay increases. Mr Kelty also dismisses the argument that a wages push in the current economic climate will exacerbate unemployment. He says:
. . . wage and salary earners are not responsible for unemployment, and can hardly be called upon again to exercise restraint.

There are one hell of a lot of people in my electorate who would really love to have the opportunity to exercise a bit of wage restraint if they could get a job, but they cannot. They would be delighted to have the opportunity to work for reduced wages-perhaps more flexible conditions of employment-if they could get a job. But they cannot get a job and they are on the scrap heap.

Not just builders labourers, but carpenters, brick layers, tilers, electricians, company accountants, consultants-people from middle management all across Australia-are hurting. The reason they are hurting is partly due to the highly inflexible industrial relations system that the Government keeps wanting to hold up.

The honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis) said that there is something sinister about Opposition policy in industrial relations. He hinted at a hidden agenda wherein the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) supposedly would like to see hours of work now moved back to 40, 48, 50, 60-or maybe more. We might exploit workers who wanted to work 50 hours a week. What the policy is all about, at the real level of where people work, is giving people the opportunity to make a choice for themselves.

The honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) said, `My goodness gracious. The honourable member for Bennelong wants to give people choice. Isn't that awful'. The Labor Party does not believe in giving people choice-it believes in coercion, it believes in direction, and it believes in control.

The Training Guarantee Act is a terrific example of how not to go about encourageing people to do things. That Act forces people to do things. Industrial relations law forces people to belong to a rigid system that can be controlled by the Government and controlled by its mates in the trade union movement.

The honourable member for Brisbane talks about unions as if they were the centre of the world, the beginning and end of the debate. I remind honourable members that only 40 per cent of people in the work force in this country are members of trade unions. It is down to about 32 per cent of those in the private work force. If honourable members come into this House tomorrow morning and debate and support my industrial relations amendment or my Industrial Relations (Membership of Associations) Bill which calls for voluntary union membership, union membership will continue to decline because public sector union membership is bound to fall once membership is voluntary.

There is one last point I want to make. The honourable member for Brisbane seemed terribly confused about Opposition policy on industrial relations. He talked about two streams, two ways to go. Let us try it once again. I have been in this House many times on this issue and I have heard the honourable member for Bennelong many times on this issue. He has quoted the policy so many times-so have I-that I would have thought it had sunk in. But let us try it one more time for the record. Firstly, if we like the centralised system and want the Commission to set the conditions, then we should stay there. Secondly, if we want vertical agreements and want to have unions negotiate with management on a vertical industry basis, then we must have section 115 of the Industrial Relations Act. But if we do not like either-and I do not very much-then we should let employees and employers at the work face level, where it really happens, opt out completely and let them decide how they want to approach their working life.

I have dealt with the second level of paranoia on the part of the leading spokesman for the Opposition on this matter, the honourable member for Bennelong. The honourable member for O'Connor, in his contribution, cited an unsubstantiated Canadian survey, which showed, apparently, that companies that have productivity deals gain 12 per cent more in profits. That is the nub of the Opposition's position in relation to industrial relations. When all is said and done, the fundamental intention of this is to reduce conditions. The intellectual gurus in New Zealand that 10 or 11 honourable members opposite, including the Leader of the Opposition, flocked over to see last week have indicated that that is clearly the intention of the legislation there, that it is quite clear that there will be a reduction in conditions.

If they were to succeed electorally, this is crucial to the whole process we are talking about. This is because there will be a very drastic downturn in the living conditions of people, if and when these kinds of measures are put in place.

Briefly, in regard to the Australian Trade Union Training Authority, these measures continue a process that TUTA has itself moved down. In the last few years there has been a saving of $560,000 through a process of cutting back on the payment of attendees who do not obtain payments through award rights. There has been an increased charge for attendance at the Clyde Cameron College itself, as well as a variety of other measures in relation to cost cutting. There has been the appointment of a national director, to ensure that its programs are more aligned with the needs of award restructuring in this country and to move most of these courses towards industrial style training, rather than having totally union oriented requirements.

In the case of the organisation that I worked with for eight years, there is a situation where some courses are taken in consultation with TUTA but with their own instructors, while in other cases they use TUTA's facilities totally. I want to mention particularly the question of cleaning service delegates courses run by our union, in conjunction with TUTA. This is another area that indicates what will happen if honourable members opposite get their way with industrial relations. The trade union movement in New South Wales, and in particular the Miscellaneous Workers Union of Australia, has protected the preference clauses for widows and single mothers in the government cleaning sector. One of the great initial moves by the Greiner Government was an attempt to slaughter those preference clauses and thus deprive those women who had lost their husbands and who depended on their jobs. Among other changes through this TUTA measure is the disappearance of State and regional councils. The other part of the legislation deals with the question of Vice Presidents and Senior Deputy Presidents.
