His current proposal is that the ACTU somehow will be sitting above these hundreds of thousands of enterprise agreements, making sure that they go according to plan.

Although the Treasurer has conceded the case, the concession for him is entirely linguistic. He concedes the case for enterprise agreements; he concedes the case for devolution of powers; he concedes the case for fixing these things at the workplace level; he concedes the case that this is the way in which productivity can be increased. But, of course, when it comes to the substantive issue, he cannot really get down to a structure that will permit it, for the kind of structure that will permit all of those things to take place is a structure that has enterprise bargaining units-with employees either in their own enterprise specific unions or in a loose association with somebody negotiating on their behalf, but negotiating as an enterprise unit. Of course, the Treasurer's idea is that we will still have industry-wide national unions and industry-wide national unions will pick off enterprises one by one according to the ACTU grand plan. And the Treasurer calls that enterprise bargaining. It is no such thing at all. The reason he cannot get to the system of enterprise bargaining that would actually work is that he cannot forgo the reduction in influence that that would mean for those national industry unions and for the ACTU generally.

I could go through many of the provisions of this Bill, including those relating to the Trade Union Training Authority, and I could, one by one, establish that they are not warranted. For example, take the Trade Union Training Authority. I think it is probably a good idea that trade union officials be trained, but why should that be done using taxpayers' money? Why should the taxpayers pay for the training of trade union officials? If trade unionism is such a good thing and if the employees of this country want to join unions and want trained officials, they will be able to provide the income necessary for it.

However, I come to the main gist of the Opposition's opposition to this Bill. That relates to the restructuring of the Industrial Relations Commission. In 1988 this Parliament enacted the Industrial Relations Act, which set up a new Industrial Relations Commission. It had a President, Deputy Presidents and Commissioners. In 1988 that was considered a reasonable structure. How is it that three years later that structure is no longer considered desirable? What major changes have occurred in the interim? We know what major changes have occurred in the interim. They are: a distaste by the ACTU for the way in which salaries were fixed in the Industrial Relations Commission; the resulting worry that that caused in the Commission; the undermining of the independence of the Commission that that led to; and, as a result, an attempt to patch it up with a new structure as if that will solve the problem, introducing new levels in between President and Deputy President-the new levels of Vice President and Senior Deputy Presidents.

In 1988 we got a new Industrial Relations Commission. That replaced the old Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. I will set it out in equation form: Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, minus Staples, equals Industrial Relations Commission. There was no reason why the Industrial Relations Commission was introduced except to get rid of a troublesome judge on the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

I would not for a moment defend all the views and judgments of Mr Justice Staples, but let me make this point: if one believes in the independence of this institution, one could not justify the extreme lengths gone to to get rid of that judge. If he had behaved badly he ought to have been removed through the proper processes, but the Government obfuscated and set up a new commission just to get rid of one troublesome judge. It is indicative of the way in which this Government treats with contempt the independence of that institution.

If I could set it out in equation form, the restructured Commission which would come about as a result of this Bill equals the old Commission over the ACTU. That means that we have to have the Commission restructured, because that is the only way the Government could keep the Commission going with the approval of the ACTU. So it has to be divided by-is it the quotient--

TALK.START.PARA: —The lowest common denominator.

—It has to be divided by the lowest common denominator, as my friend the honourable member for Chisholm says. Let me make it clear that I have always held the view that the Industrial Relations Commission, constituted by statute, is entitled to the respect that the statute confers upon it. The statute confers independence upon it. I do not believe that that independence should be undermined.

SPEECH.PARA: If one has differences with the Industrial Relations Commission, if one thinks that it is not behaving as it ought, one ought to change the statute. But, whilst that statute constitutes it as an independent body, it ought to be given the respect that it deserves. Of course, this Government will not give it that respect. The ACTU will not give it that respect. When the first wage decision since 1983 came down that did not agree with the accord partners, the Government and the ACTU walked away from it.

The doctrine of this Government and of the ACTU in relation to the Industrial Relations Commission is this: `All decisions which support us are immutable and all decisions which do not support us are totally negotiable'. That is the view that they have of the Industrial Relations Commission.

All the rest of the Gleeson reports and all of those recommendations will not obviate that one fundamental point of contempt that this Government and the ACTU have shown for the Industrial Relations Commission. If one wants to change the role of the Industrial Relations Commission-and I believe it ought to be changed-one ought to do it in an honest way by amending the statute, not by leaving the statute in place, pretending that it has statutory independence and then at every available opportunity undermining that independence.

I want to make it clear to this House that nobody has undermined the independence of the Industrial Relations Commission as have the ACTU and this Government. There is no basis on which they can ever again stand and say that it is an independent institution, there to independently arbitrate between parties to industrial disputes. There is no basis for it. The Government and the ACTU cannot maintain that argument. They have disclosed their own contempt. They have mortally wounded the independence and the standing of that Commission, and it ought to be clear that they did it for the most base reasons-their own political interests. If the Industrial Relations Commission as a result has difficulty in the field upholding its decisions and its principles, it is their fault because they walked away from it in the most contemptuous way. For many reasons this is contemptuous legislation. It ought to be rejected, and I urge the House to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an interesting experience to sit in this House during this debate on the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill and the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) and to hear the Opposition's attitude towards the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). I wonder at its pretence to ever form government. The ACTU plays a major role in the Australian community. Yet, if one dealt with the pattern of the Opposition's remarks on a day by day, week by week and year by year basis, one would swear that in fact it regards the ACTU as an enemy of the Australian community. I find that extraordinary.
—Ha!

—The honourable member for Chisholm laughs, but I find it extraordinary because it is an unusual attitude from two parties which pretend to government. I say that not because we on this side would say that everything the trade union movement does is correct, but we recognise that in the ACTU we have responsible decision makers who play a part in restructuring the Australian economy and in bringing about desirable outcomes.

SPEECH.PARA: It was interesting to hear the remarks of the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) on this particular day when we have seen this extraordinary inflation result. We are seeing the consequence of an approach to wages policy, and of other economic policies, which has now resulted in lower rates of inflation without massive industrial disputes. One can contrast that with the experience of the Opposition when it was in government and its pattern. For members of the Opposition to come into this place and deride the ACTU-which is what the honourable member for Higgins has just done and what his counterparts tend to do-is just an extraordinary approach to policy making.

The ACTU is a responsible group of people seeking to represent its members, and also to play a part in restructuring the Australian economy. A contrast would be if we were to come here on a day by day basis and disparage everything that the Confederation of Australian Industry or the National Farmers Federation said. There are times when we do take issue with both those organisations-but not through a constant stream of criticism and abuse such as I have heard about the ACTU for eight years.

I will say, incidentally, that I think the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) is remarkable because he does not do that. We know why. It is because he is a person of considerable stature. He has been around and he knows how it works. It might be all right for people such as the honourable member for Higgins to unload a bit of ideology from time to time, but the fact is that in government one has to work with and modify institutions. I make that point very strongly. I do not very often take issue with Opposition members in this respect, but I do on this occasion because I find it just extraordinary to hear, after eight years in this place, that the tune about the ACTU has not changed.

If we look at any of the major reforms that we have tried in industrial relations in Australia, we find that the ACTU has been part of that process. Of course it represents the trade union movement and of course it does not always say the same thing that we, the Government, the Opposition, the Parliament or the community might say. That is by the nature of it. But one cannot always criticise it for having bad motives because I do not think that applies. I also do not think it applies in respect of the remarks of the honourable member for Higgins when he spoke about the independence of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (AIRC).

As we heard earlier today, looking at the approach of the Opposition to the role of the Reserve Bank of Australia, the question of independence of institutions is important. We cannot have it both ways; we cannot have a monetary policy by which we instruct the Reserve Bank of Australia-from the way I read the remarks-and we cannot then say that we are concerned about the independence of institutions. We must have institutions which are independent and respected.

That is the next matter I shall deal with. One of the issues I am particularly pleased about is this question of the joint jurisdiction of State and Federal commissions. I note here that the role of Commissioner Halliwell and Commissioner Coleman from Western Australia will be very important in the role of this joint Federal-State jurisdiction. We are getting improvements in the way the Australian Industrial Relations Commission is working; we are getting improvements in the way the whole industrial structure is working.

The only way to examine an approach to wages policy is to do so without the sorts of remarks I hear far too often about the ACTU. From my dealings with it, and I am certain it applies to the dealings of my colleagues, one cannot ascribe bad motives to the ACTU on most occasions. One can certainly ascribe very strong motives, and for that I respect it; but one cannot ascribe bad motives. As I said, the honourable member for Bennelong did not get onto that track, but the honourable member for Higgins did. It might satisfy him and his constituency, but it does not satisfy the debate in which we are involved, and that is the crucial issue. We are involved in a debate about wages policy and about the role of the AIRC and its recent decision.

There has been a lot of discussion in this Parliament about this recent decision. The Government took as a view that the accord was central to the whole strategy of both wages and prices policy in this country. The nexus between those, the properly negotiated positions of the accord and the trade-offs which are part of those elements, are very important. The fact that the AIRC chose to ignore those is another matter of which I will speak in a moment.

We regard it as important for us as a government and for the ACTU to work together. One of the reasons for that is because of the outcome we get in terms of reduced inflation and reduced wage pressure. Clearly, there are other reasons. We have much reduced demand and we have an economy in recession; I recognise that they are factors which underpin a lower rate of inflation. It would be folly to claim otherwise.

An element of that is the wages outcome, so the accord is seen as central. It is obviously going to be a matter of judgment by people in this chamber as to whether or not we always accept the umpire's decision. One of the things that bedevil industrial relations is that too often there are trade unionists and there are employers who do not accept the umpire's decision. That is a worrying thing. In that respect, we do get anecdotes about behaviour amongst some trade unionists who are ignoring the umpire's decision. They are ones that we as a community need to address.

At the same time, we have also what I think is a very significant issue, that is, the element of non-compliance in relation to 3 per cent superannuation. We have seen a lot of employers who have not complied-sometimes, I believe, out of ignorance because the information has not been put in front of them. That is understandable, and that is a job to be done. At other times it is simply because either they think it is a way of reducing their costs-and it is, because there has been a wage cut-or their circumstances are so tight economically that, when they are faced with other bills, superannuation is the last that they tend to pay. Whatever the causes of that are, as a community we have to examine this question of the superannuation arrangements and the proper payment of that 3 per cent that was dealt with in the past.

It is interesting that that brings us to this current case. The Industrial Relations Commission has said that it would welcome the opportunity to look at the question of the future of superannuation. I think there is merit in saying that we as a community ought to be examining this whole question of superannuation in respect of three issues: firstly, the current levels of compliance; secondly, the future of superannuation so that we get to a quantum of superannuation which makes it worth while for people to be in it, because at this stage the amounts involved are relatively small; and thirdly, if we are going to have a retirement incomes policy which has, on the one hand, pension payments and, on the other hand, superannuation, how the community regards that and what the strategy for it is to be.

Incidentally, clearly an approach which looks at this issue and is successful will result in a greater lift to our national savings, which I think both sides of Parliament would regard as significant, because our current savings ratio is unacceptably low when we look at the overall needs. As a consequence, we have lived off other people's savings; hence the effect on the current account. The whole pattern is there.
In terms of that specific decision, my view is that there is merit in responding to what the Commission said. I think that is something that will take time to work through, but that is where I stand.

In conclusion, I think it is very important that the whole question of the future of the industrial relations system be still under review. It is never fixed in concrete, nor should it be. It is a living institution in which the players in the game play a significant part. Many employers to whom I have spoken respond by saying that there are many merits in the industrial relations system.

I heard the honourable member for Bennelong talk about the Power Brewing experience, but I think that when we look at individual companies and talk about the experience of individual company's management and employees, there is a lot to be said for getting good relations in the workplace, which result in those types of outcomes. I do not think there would be a lot of opposition to that amongst honourable members-certainly not from me-because if we can get those sorts of outcomes and they bring increases in productivity and improvements in workplace behaviour, clearly they have to be the goal.

The mechanism to get there is clearly one that is a matter for debate between our two sides of the chamber. I am still of the view that I do not think we will get there by throwing away the whole system and starting again. Frankly, I do not think the honourable member for Bennelong is saying that.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I am not. I am giving them choices.
—But I--
—A choice not to, if they don't want to use a union.

—What worries me is the comments of the honourable member for Higgins and this ideological position that the ACTU, ipso facto, is bad news and it is a conspiracy. I cannot accept it, and the community cannot accept it either. It is not relevant. It has never been recognised properly by some people, such as the honourable member for Higgins, that the capacity in the system for things like award variations has always been there anyway. Many people have come to me and said, `Look, I know all about this question of bargaining with the individual employer, but my son is 17 and he is working down in Osmond Park. His boss decides to give him a pay cut. What does he do?'. We have the New Zealand experience already on the table and it is not very attractive at all.
—You are just worried about film clips.

—No; with the documentation. We have had some people go over, have a look and come back and talk to us about it. I recently had an extraordinary experience of the abuse of the system where people in fact were underpaid. I talked about it in the Parliament.
—That happens now?

—It happens now. The parents came to me first and said, `Look, is there a union, Ron, that covers this?'. Finally, we found out that the Miscellaneous Workers Union could provide coverage, but it was not until the Miscellaneous Workers Union began to look at this experience with VIP Cleaning Services that we got a redress. These people were being paid $5 per hour and the employer wanted to pay them $2 per hour, which I found a bit rich. The employer was simply exploiting the situation. I do not think many parents and young people want to go down that path. I do not see any great surge for that in my community.
—Nobody does; but surely if people do not want to use a union, they should not be forced to use one. That is the whole crux of our argument.

—We are talking about a wages policy and an industrial relations system because of the role of unions in setting it up. What I get from people like the honourable member for Higgins-not from the honourable member for Bennelong--
—Ron, just answer my question.

—I am. What I get from people like the honourable member for Higgins is that the ACTU, ipso facto, is bad news; that there is a conspiracy between it and the Government and we have to get rid of it. I do not find that and I cannot accept it. I think that until my dying day that will be the position. I think it is the thing that my Government colleagues hold to very strongly and people on the Opposition side do not hold to-some of them do not. Many employers do not hold to the Opposition's position; they hold to our position, for the good reasons that I have indicated. I conclude my remarks on this point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anderson Mr J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker--
—Reasonableness has just gone out the window.

—I beg your pardon! I will come to the honourable member in a moment. I find it interesting that the Labor movement claims to be so proud of its treatment of its own members and that it constantly crows that we on our side of the House, and those who might be connected with us, cannot, or could not, run a satisfactory industrial relations policy. We often hear, for example, that our policy and our approach is a recipe for a wages blow-out. Inherent in this reasoning is the belief that if we cease to control employees, they will react by breaking out and behaving irrationally and against both their own interests and the nation's best interests.

SPEECH.PARA: The irony of this seems to escape Government members, from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) downwards. The irony lies in the fact that it takes a very low view of Australian workers. It is to confirm the view of the Industrial Relations Commission (IRC) when it recently said that we are not yet mature enough in this country to cope with enterprise agreements. Implicit in that condemnation is the patronising attitude that it is necessary to determine what is best for the bulk of the Australian work force and then to impose those decisions upon workers from on high, because to allow them to run their own affairs would be to run the risk of industrial anarchy and economic mayhem, as our workers are not capable of thinking out their own best future.

This narrow and unsatisfactory view is reflected again in some of the material now before us. For example, the reticence of the Government in getting on with its review of Comcare provisions so as to allow people over the age of 65 to enjoy Comcare cover reeks not only of the Government's tardiness in making sensible reforms but also of its commitment to the centralised control over the way we work, the way we are paid and the way we generally behave in the workplace.

On 6 November last in this place, in a debate on the future of the Australian National Maritime Museum in Darling Harbour in Sydney, we saw the then Minister for Tourism and Arts, Mr Simmons, trying to defend the indefensible when the Opposition sought to move amendments to the relevant legislation that was before us at that stage to allow people who were older that 65 to serve on the museum board, because, as it stands, people over 65 cannot be on the board of directors. The principal reason given for that related to the inflexible nature of Comcare and the fact that anyone over 65 who served on the board could not be covered.

On that occasion the honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney), in the committee stage, pointed out that this was an absurd situation and, in reference to something that I said, referred to my having pointed out that many of people who are peculiarly able to contribute to the understanding of the issues that will be faced by that museum, people who are particularly aware of the history of maritime matters, may be people of mature years. In those circumstances, he said:
. . . we are potentially depriving this Museum of people who could be of enormous value to it.
He went on to say that he had a second broad concern which was a matter of simple justice. He said:

. . . it is the view of the Opposition parties-a view which is reflected in our formal and published policies-that those people in Australia who are aged 65 and over should not be treated as second-class citizens. It is our view that those people are entitled to be dealt with without discrimination on the grounds of age.

Yet here tonight we find that this same issue appears to be no further along the road to resolution at all. The refusal to employ people over 65 is offensive enough in itself. In this particular case, the reason was quite trivial. Yet we find that just as the Minister then sought to defend the Government's policies at the time, very little has happened since. In rather convoluted English he said:

The important point that I keep coming back to is that we do have a process in train at present to look at the very issues that the Opposition is raising. Somehow or other I am being accused in some sort of cursory way of being dismissive of the amendments. I have sought to explain to the House that that is far from my intention. We are very conscious of age considerations and it is for that reason that the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) sought to extend this process further. We are conscious of it not just within my portfolio responsibility but right across the broad area of Government responsibility. In that context, we are looking at the total question of age and some of the inconsistencies that I acknowledge are there at present.

That was on 6 November. We do not seem to have got very far, if anywhere at all, in the process of review that we were promised was being undertaken at that time. I understand that amendments will be moved tonight, amendments which should not need moving. If the Government accepts them, as it ought, some of these absurd discriminations against people over 65 will end. So, too, will the small chink of the Government's overweening control of the workplace and of the people in it. Why should those over 65 who want to work-many of whom still have a great deal to contribute-not be able to do so? This whole question of breaking down this drab hand of control that the Labor movement and the IRC-the club, if you like-seem to feel must be kept imposed is something that is surely quite critical for Australia.

The Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths), who is at the table, knows something about the bureaucratic imposition of labour market control from the top end. He presides over the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) which, amongst other things, runs around 1,400 or 1,500 meat inspectors, plus quite a few who are redundant and do not actually do any meat inspections. The Government, despite regular promises that there would be no increase in cost recovery above 60 per cent, now charges an amount of 100 per cent as from 1 January this year. Abattoirs across the country now find them themselves forking out very close to $65,000 per annum for meat inspectors who earn, on average, $31,000.

We have heard consistent promises in response to the concerns of the meat industry that if 100 per cent cost recovery is paid, major improvements in efficiency and work practices would be granted. We have not seen much of that. Consequently, we have just had a dispute in New South Wales where the domestic abattoirs refuse to pay 100 per cent cost recovery. In response, the Minister withdrew the provision of AQIS inspection services. Amongst other things, that produced the farcical situation at Cowra where $200,000 worth of prime meat was written off as dog food. It was inspected by two fully qualified meat inspectors but they were regarded as illegal because there are normally eight. The real issue is that it would appear that we do not need anything like eight meat inspectors to do the job.

It becomes a question of protecting inefficient work practices and not getting on with the job of streamlining this operation. We hear from the Minister that streamlining and reductions are taking place. Yet I am told that of the 30 abattoirs that were surveyed towards the end of last year in this regard not one recorded a drop in inspection manning levels and some recorded an increase.

I think the challenge is there for the Minister, AQIS and for the whole inspection service to answer some of the questions that are floating around out there. Why are we so grossly inefficient in meat inspection services in this country compared to our American trading competitors? Why does it cost a plant in Australia up to twice as much as an equivalent plant in New Zealand for inspection services? These are the sorts of areas that need to be examined as a matter of urgency if we are to develop a lean and efficient economy of the sort that allows us to compete in international trading places. It seems astonishing to me that we can have a major industry statement designed to set out initiatives for the boosting of our export performance and yet at the same time we go on crucifying the few winners that we do have.

It seems to me that our industrial relations policy is designed to promote genuine industrial relations-I emphasise the word `relations'-genuine consensus, a genuine identification of common goals by both workers and employers and the scope for both parties to work towards their mutually identified and mutually advantageous ends. The Government's model of centralised control is based on a model of confrontation by its very determination to impose discipline from above in the belief that the failure to do so will result in chaos.

Australia can no longer afford this kind of buffoonery. The number of Australians who know that is increasing daily. We have heard a bit of talk tonight about the number of Australians who belong to trade unions in this country. I place on record the comment made by a trade union official to an acquaintance of mine the other day. He said that if the union movement cannot make itself more relevant-if we were to introduce compulsory, genuine voluntary unionism in this country-it would be lucky to hold 10 per cent of private sector work force.

The other day in this place the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) claimed in his contribution to a matter of public importance that much of our industrial relations problems could be traced to poor management. I think this is the other side of the coin. I want to touch on some of these issues tonight. I frankly think that he had a point, though I, in turn, would say that in our current plight that is all the more reason for us to do something about reforming the way we work and live out our lives in the workplace. Lord Nelson was reported to have once said to the King:
Give me decent lieutenants and I will build you a proper navy.

That is relevant for us to consider. I want to place on record some very interesting comments which were recorded by Ross Gittins in the Sydney Morning Herald last Monday morning. He quotes Dr Michael Deeley, boss of ICI Australia, who said:

We need to move from seeing employees as an undesirable and variable cost to seeing them as an important investment; as the key to improving performance through fully utilising their talents. For such a cultural shift to be successful, a company's policies and actions must reflect a change of attitude of management to its employees.
There is a need to move from a culture where employees are controlled, to one of commitment. This is where employees are trusted and empowered;-
not controlled from on top-

where management provides support and motivation by focusing on performance and outcome. In a workplace based on commitment, the individual will have a job that is flexibly defined and part of a comprehensive career structure . . . to problem-solving involving the company, its employees and their unions.

Our experience demonstrates that shared goals and values-combined with empowerment and trust-can create more productive workplaces, and benefit both the company and employees. Agreements negotiated at individual sites are the obvious products, but it is the process by which they are reached that is crucial.

I would assume that the first thing one could rule out in terms of that process to enterprise based agreements would be the Prime Minister's approach to the problems of the waterfront whereby the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions have combined to bludgeon the life out of the employers until they agree. That is not enterprise based bargaining.

To conclude, it seems to me that we need to rethink as a matter of great urgency the way we work and pay ourselves in this country if we are to have a future. That is broadly acknowledged. No successful economy in the world has a centralised system like ours. It is true that Russia and China do have centralised systems and perhaps they could match our model. But they are hardly successful economies. Nor will we be until we start to show a little more maturity in this whole area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak tonight on the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1991. I was not too sure whether I was going to get the opportunity to do so. Of course, industrial relations is a very important issue to members on this side of the House. Our record since 1983 in the industrial relations arena is something of which we can be justly proud. That has been emphasised in this place today not only in this debate but also during Question Time and discussion on the matter of public importance.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill specifically seeks to amend the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988, known as the CERC Act, and the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973, known at the RT Act. It also proposes certain consequential amendments to other legislation with the one exception to this being certain machinery amendments to the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988.

I would like to speak on one of the elements of the Bill which are of relevance to the many Commonwealth employees in my electorate of Oxley and, indeed, throughout Australia. While this legislation has something of a direct impact on Commonwealth employees, I would like to take this opportunity to give credit to the hundreds of Commonwealth employees in the Ipswich and west Moreton area working in Commonwealth Government departments and agencies such as the Australian Construction Services at the Amberley Royal Australian Air Force base, which is located just outside of the city of Ipswich. It is fitting, given the commitment of these men and women, that they are to be rewarded with the more flexible compensation arrangements that this Bill proposes. It is also appropriate that the scheme itself is to be amended accordingly to facilitate more effective operation of the Act.

I would like to turn to some other elements of industrial relations. As I mentioned at the start of my speech, the advances follow the equitable industrial relations thrust that has become a hallmark of this Government-a direction that has brought great benefits to the workers of this country.

Against this commitment, we have seen the Opposition come out over the years with many variations of what is essentially the same thing-and that is a plan that would erode the lifestyles and values of the average Australian and certainly the average Australian family.

It has been some weeks now since we have heard the latest variation of the coalition's draconian industrial relations agenda. The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) has put on record that he is so committed to the implementation of the Opposition's enterprise bargaining arrangements that the Opposition would be prepared to subject the Australian people to a double dissolution if, after the election of a coalition government, the reforms were knocked back in the Senate.

I read in today's paper that the Premier of New South Wales has indicated his policy and attitudes to the people of New South Wales. Hopefully, the people of New South Wales will take note of what he is offering.

I want to quote from an interview that was conducted between the Opposition spokesman for industrial relations and Matthew Abraham on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio on Thursday, 21 February this year. In that interview the Opposition spokesman clearly spelt out what the coalition would do to the industrial relations framework if it were lucky enough to be elected to office. After the poor performance that we have seen day after day from members of the Opposition, the people of Australia will certainly find out at some time the shallowness of their policies. In that interview, the honourable member for Bennelong said:

We would put up our industrial relations legislation immediately a change of government took place, and if it were blocked in the Senate, it would be back again in three months, and I would be saying to the new Government, in the event of it being rejected again, that it should seek a double dissolution because reform of the industrial relations system is not only necessary in its own right but it is the absolute cornerstone of the economic reform program that we have.

As I mentioned before, the Premier of New South Wales is making the same sorts of threats to the people of New South Wales. I can assure honourable members opposite that this dictatorial attitude is not the way to go about industrial relations reform and will certainly not win favour with the Australian electorate.

It is rather interesting to note that during the recent Labour Day celebrations in Queensland the chairman of the local chamber of commerce made an attack on workers in which he advocated taking away from them this one day that they celebrated each year. He is also on record as saying that workers should be required to go back to working 45 hours a week as well as foregoing maternity leave and leave loadings-you name it, anything that has been of benefit to workers over the last 100 years. This man wants to take us back 100 years. I have received outstanding support for what I have been doing for the people of my electorate. I take this opportunity to thank them and my local trades and labour council for the support that they have given me in my efforts to highlight to the people of my electorate the draconian attitude that was expounded by the chairman of the local chamber of commerce, who obviously has been reading Liberal Party policy papers.

In that same interview, the honourable member for Bennelong went on to describe the industrial relations framework as `the total linchpin' and `the tent pole' of the economic picture. I must say that I concur with the honourable member on this point. However, when it comes to providing the best system to make our industries internationally competitive, I am glad that I am on this side of the House, sitting with those who truly represent the workers of this country.

When the Opposition's spokesman implies that the industrial relations differences between the Opposition and the Government are the linchpin of economic policy, he is dead right. What is highlighted here is the fundamental difference between the Government's unprecedented success in achieving predictable and sustainable wage outcomes and the Opposition's complete lack of a policy in this area.

We have heard all the rhetoric about enterprise bargaining and profit sharing. But I ask honourable members opposite to look at the reality behind their blurred vision of ideals and come up with real alternatives if they believe the Government's modus operandi is wrong.

What employers want is to be able to budget for long term decisions and an integral part of that is to know how much they will need to allow for wage increases in coming years. And that is exactly what employers have been delivered through the wages and incomes accord since 1983. It has everything to do with a wages policy and obviously those opposite have no idea of what a wages policy is all about.

The accord means that when any Australian employer wants to know how much he needs to allow for wage increases in, for instance, 1991, the answer is contained in the proposals in the accord. Under the Opposition plan, there would be 1,001 different wage outcomes for 1,001 different companies, making it impossible to set any national wage goals, let alone achieve them.

There has also been the recent obsession within the Liberal Party with a consumption tax. This highlights the ignorance on the other side of the House of the wage-tax equation. Today we heard the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) speak about the effects that a consumption tax would have on inflation in this country. The Liberal consumption tax plan is riddled with social inequities. We need only look at the figures to see the enormous gap that would develop between the rich and the poor under the tax regime proposed by those members opposite. A consumption tax and its accompanying impacts on inflation would have particular dire effects for low income earners.

When speaking in this House earlier this session on taxation legislation, I made reference to the specific implications of such a tax. Given the relevance of those remarks to the broader industrial picture, I feel that they are worth noting again. Based on a consumption tax of only 10 per cent-we do not know the actual percentage that the Opposition is speaking about but I have heard figures mentioned of up to 15 and 20 per cent-people on an income of $18,000 a year would get a tax cut of $2.05 a week but because of a 9 per cent increase in prices, their net take-home pay would be $22.43 a week less. People on incomes of $45,000 a year would take home an extra $17.85 a week while at the higher end of the wage scale those on incomes of $125,000 a year would end up $259 a week better off. The lesson here is simple: the higher the wage, the higher the benefit under a consumption tax.

In contrast with this, the Hawke Government has provided genuine commitment to making sure Australian workers get a fair deal through a wages system that also provides predictable outcomes by which clear economic directions can be set. For example, when we look at the case of people on an income of $18,000 a year, we find that such people have benefited under the 1 January tax cuts afforded to them by the stability of the accord-a tax cut of $4.15 a week, equivalent to a pre-tax wage rise of $5.95 a week, without the 9 per cent inflation that would accompany the Liberal alternative, the consumption tax.

We have heard all the allegations by the Opposition that a consumption tax was talked about by the Government in 1985, but again they have missed the point. The Government's intention was to use it as a means of reducing the pay-as-you-earn tax scales, something that we have been able to achieve without a consumption tax. I remind honourable members opposite that this has been largely due to the success of the wages and incomes accord, through the stability it has provided in delivering predictable wage outcomes.

Let us not forget that it is what ends up in the hip pocket at the end of the week that matters most to our workers. As exemplified by the case I have just mentioned, the Government recognises this. The Opposition clearly does not. I am sorry to disappoint honourable members opposite, but their jigsaw of suggestions to make the Australian machine work better just will not fit together.

I also take this opportunity to put on record my complete disdain for the Opposition's support for extended trading hours for the service sector. Its position on this issue is deplorable. In the same Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio interview to which I have just referred, the honourable member for Bennelong again said that the Opposition policy on this issue will be to leave it to people to `make their own agreements without the interference of the Industrial Relations Commission or the trade union movement, in a veto sense, and that they can decide that penalty rates will go'. That is another attack on the workers.

The people of Australia should also be aware that the Opposition views penalty rates in service industries as ridiculous and as being the sort of thing that ought to go. The workers of Australia should know these points, because penalty rates are the only small incentive and compensation afforded to low income earners for the irregular hours that they are asked to work.

What the Opposition forgets is that the type of people who would be affected by such a move are the low income earners. We are not talking about the high fliers who are sitting pretty on their $50,000-plus annual salaries. In this argument, the Opposition is talking about people on very average incomes, who rely heavily on overtime and penalty rates to make ends meet, and who rely on their leave loading just to have their holiday once a year. Imagine the effects of taking away the leave loading on our tourist industry! From surveys I have seen, I know that the leave loading is one of the areas that is most supported by families, and it has an impact. Families benefit greatly from it and it has been extremely popular. I would like to see the honourable member for Bennelong get by on an income of $15,000 or $18,000 a year with a family of three children without the benefit of a few penalty rates.

There is also the issue of family values and how they would be eroded under such regimes. What of the children in families where both parents work in service industries? If the Opposition had its way, most of those children would grow up rarely seeing both their parents at the same time. The concession by the honourable member for Bennelong that our 24-hour-a-day, seven-day-a-week society requires services to be provided around the clock shows total disregard for the rights of families working in these areas.

SPEECH.PARA: This evening I want to talk about the very fast train. There is a fascination in this country with great transport projects-whether they are big aeroplanes, big bridges, big trucks, big ships or big trains. They mesmerise many people. It seems the greater the scheme, the grander the vision and the more likely it is to mesmerise even the sceptics-people who, in normal circumstances, would apply a much tougher rule of assessment to such projects.

It amazes me how politicians fall for these kinds of projects. Somehow the Alice Springs to Darwin railway was considered to be a magnificent project which Australia should have-so they said. But the same people who are espousing those views are clamouring for reductions in Federal expenditure. That is just one example, and what examples such as that do is distract public attention and government attention from doing the things in transport which ought to be done; doing the things which will substantially improve productivity and efficiency. Improving transport efficiency is about doing the things that need to be done; it is not about dreams and visions.

As far back as the mid-1970s, the Bureau of Transport Economics submitted a report to this Parliament that showed that a very positive result would flow from the upgrading of the Melbourne to Sydney railway. Nothing happened, and a change of government occurred in 1975. In about 1979 Prime Minister Fraser wanted a great project to grab the public imagination-something that the people would really look up to. That project, you might remember, Mr Speaker, was the electrification of the Melbourne to Sydney railway line. But, like all other grand visions, it did not stand the economic test. It took some years until, eventually, the studies were carried out and they showed that it was economic nonsense so it did not proceed.

The result of it was that, again, attention was distracted from doing what ought to have been done then-that was, the upgrading of the Melbourne to Sydney line, the extending of the passing loops, the widening of the curves and the easing of the gradients. These measures would have provided a very positive return to the taxpayer and to the railway system. They would have halved the journey time, doubled the capacity, and contributed substantially to improved transport efficiency.

Similarly, on this basis, along came the very fast train (VFT) proposal in 1984, a magnificent project, a private sector project. It was going to take only twice as long as the air journey from Sydney to Melbourne. It did not need Government assistance, but it was promoted on the basis that the imprimatur of Government approval would make it easier to raise private capital. That proposal has changed to one that is now highly geared, with 80 per cent loan money and 20 per cent in equity, and seeking substantial taxpayer assistance of some $1.4 billion.

In considering this, does anyone seriously believe that by the time such a project was built it would be able to stand up to the competition of a deregulated aviation environment, where aviation would be providing greater services to Melbourne taking half the time of the VFT? The simple fact is that those who want to travel cheaply drive by private car. Those who want to get there in a hurry will go by air. There is no way that one can reasonably envisage that in the future the airline industry will stand by and see, as the VFT proponents claim, half of its traffic being diverted to a VFT. As to whether the project has commercial viability, that is a matter of commercial decision by those interested, and those interested ought to be promoting the project on a commercial basis and should keep their hands out of the taxpayer's pocket.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walker Mr F.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We all know that the Liberal Party of Australia has a fanatical commitment to the user pays principle and the principle of cutting government services and expenditures. There is no unit of the Liberal Party more obsessive about these two concepts than the Government of New South Wales, led by Margaret Thatcher's most ardent disciple, Premier Greiner. That is why, in the face of election promises to the contrary, the election of the Greiner Government in 1988 saw a rash of increases in government fees and charges-from land tax to education expenses, from fuel tax and motor vehicle registration to traffic fines. There was no attempt to provide equity for the poor or underprivileged with increases of that sort. A privileged wealthy few were given land tax and stamp duty concessions. One privileged group received a concession in land tax of $80m. We saw the unemployed, the pensioners, handicapped people and families bear the brunt of it all.

SPEECH.PARA: In my electorate, the cruelest impost was the huge increase in railway fares. Robertson is a commuter electorate with many thousands of workers travelling for over an hour into the city each day. The electorate also has many pensioners who travel off-peak either to the city or on excursions. The lives of these commuters and pensioners were difficult enough already without their train fares being hiked up by huge amounts-in one instance, by 18 per cent. These amounts were far in excess of the consumer price index.

That brings me to the point of my contribution tonight; that is, to tell the House and the people of Australia what `Tricky Nicky' is up to in the New South Wales election. Just as in 1988, when he promised that there would be no fare increases and then immediately reneged and hiked fares far in excess of inflation, I am informed by the Australian Railways Union that the Greiner Government already has in place secret plans not only to increase fares yet again but also to reduce services to the central coast of New South Wales. The Greiner Government has a secret timetable, which has already been prepared and approved, which virtually decimates off-peak train travel to the central coast.

If Greiner wins the election, trains will only run every two hours from most stations and hourly from the major stations in place of the 30-minute service that we have enjoyed for a long time. Not only will that occur, but the whole railway system will be closed down at 10 p.m. every night until 5 a.m. the next morning. People who want to travel at that time will have to catch a bus. Catching a bus to the central coast is not convenient.

As if the train travellers do not have enough complaints already, with the late running of trains on the central coast, which is notorious, with the many breakdowns that occur between Hawkesbury River and Cowan, causing many people to be delayed-in these hard times, some of them have lost their jobs because of the constant delays-and with the many signal faults that occur with monotonous regularity that travellers also have to put up with, the Greiner Government is now going to phase-out the inter-urban carriages. My constituents enjoy the inter-urban carriages; they are very nice and they have toilets in them. When one is travelling for well over an hour-the delays that occur are sometimes for several hours-it is nice to have a toilet. The Greiner Government is going to replace the inter-urban carriages with the ordinary electric carriages from the city system. That, of course, is something that the pensioners, in particular, will find very difficult to cope with, as will the other commuters.

I think the people of the central coast have a very obvious choice on 25 May: they can vent their justifiable anger at Mr Greiner and his Ministers for what they are doing to the railway system of New South Wales and vote for Bob Carr's team. That team, like the Labor Party in the past when in government, has given and will keep undertakings to maintain services; to limit fares to the consumer price index, which both the Wran and the Unsworth governments did; to retain inter-urban carriages; to create diversion loops between Woy Woy and Cowan so that breakdowns could be dealt with almost immediately instead of the hour which it takes now; to provide commuter car parks at Woy Woy and Gosford-that is a reality, because the Federal Government is funding it-to staff Narrawa Station so that people in that huge and rapidly developing area can actually buy train tickets in the morning, and to set up a commuter committee in the area so that commuters' needs are looked at.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid The Hon N.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 18 April 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the cost of the gun component of the Anzac Ship project.
(2) How much of the sum referred to in part (1) will be spent in Australia.
(3) What are the offset arrangements with respect to the gun component of the project.
(4) Were other options which would have increased local content considered; if so, to what extent.
(5) Did 0TO Melara, an Italian contender for the contract to supply the gun, offer a greater percentage of Australian content than did the successful contender.
(6) Why was greater support not given for local industry, particularly Australian Defence Industries.
(7) Which gun was preferred by the RAN.
(8) Has the ADI's Bendigo facility received subcontracts for any work on the Anzac Ship project; if so, what approximate sum is involved.
(9) What scope is there for further tendering by ADI's heavy engineering division.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bilney The Hon G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The contract with Australian Marine Engineering Consolidated (AMECON) for the construction of the ten Anzac ships is on a lump sum basis. It is therefore not possible to identify separately all costs associated with the fitting of the 127mm gun.

The contract between the Commonwealth and FMC Corporation for the supply of the guns for all ten ships, together with associated spares and technical services is priced at $145 million (April 1988 prices).

The additional cost to the project of fitting the 127mm gun rather than the 76mm gun originally intended is $105 million (April 1988 prices) for the eight Australian ships. This amount includes up to $5 million in Australian Industry Assistance funding to cover tooling and startup costs to allow Australian manufacturers to compete on an equal basis with established overseas suppliers.
(2) The contract with FMC includes Australian Content of approximately $34 million (April 1988 prices).
(3) The contract includes an obligation to achieve a further $33 million (April 1988 prices) of Defence offsets.

(4) Each of the contending manufacturers original offers included greater local content but each required a substantial premium on the contract price to achieve this higher level. Since the work will utilise an existing industry capability but not provide any new capability, the payment of the premium could not be justified.

(6) The total industry program for the gun contract is $67 million or some 46% of the contract price. This could only have been increased if the Commonwealth was willing to pay substantial additional premiums to obtain the additional work. The $5 million of Industry Assistance funding referred to above was the maximum that could be justified by the nature of the work to be obtained.

The local content in the gun will be under sub-contracts awarded to Australian companies by FMC Corporation on the basis of competitive tendering. The Government will not influence the selection process to exercise a preference for Australian Defence Industries or any other company.
(7) Both guns were assessed as acceptable against the RAN and RNZN performance criteria. The FMC gun was selected after a comprehensive evaluation of all factors.

(8) ADI Weapons and Engineering Division at Bendigo has received sub-contracts in respect of the ANZAC Ship Project and is in negotiation for further work including work relating to the gun. Disclosure of the extent and nature of this activity is the prerogative of ADI Management.
